DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to take the necessary action in the Budget to reduce the likelihood of Australia being faced with intervention by the International Monetary Fund if there was another commodity price slide.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition raises this matter of public importance today because of the divisions in the Government between the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Those divisions go to the core of government and, precariously for Australia, to the core of economic policy. This is not some slight spat; this is a division of deeply held and differing views. It is no coincidence that the Minister who is spelling it out as it is, warning of the dangers, is the Minister who is not seeking the leadership of his Party and our nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The tape of the Finance Minister's remarks is now available. It was not available yesterday. Among other things, he said that, first, on the macro-situation, Australia is certainly not out of trouble. Secondly, he is concerned about complacency and a lack of political courage. Thirdly, he believes we may go further down the Argentinean road. Fourthly, he believes that if there is another commodity price slide, our situation is so perilous that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) would knock on our door again. Fifthly, he correctly says that a country with a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country which has few options, and he spells them out in terms which are similar to those of the Opposition, namely, to cut ongoing expenditure. Sixthly, he then homes in on what he says is the fundamental cause of our problem, namely, the current account deficit: we are consuming more from abroad, including, of course, the interest we have to pay abroad, than we have been selling abroad. That is precisely what the Opposition has been saying.

The Finance Minister's criticisms cut through the facade the Treasurer has crafted over the Budget like a canopy and go to the thrust of our criticism, namely, that this Government is stalling the pace of adjustment and thereby placing the economy at risk. There is entrenched division here and it manifested itself yesterday in the Treasurer's public criticism of the Finance Minister and, according to reports, of the Treasurer's private demand to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that Senator Walsh be sacked.

This is a great and tempting field to furrow for any opposition, but I simply put it before the House today-this division and fight among the two-for behind the division is the very well-being of every Australian man, woman and child, and it goes to the very future of our country. I believe that it is not the stuff of petty politics-to simply banter about what Walsh said and what Keating said. We must look behind it. The petty politics, if you like, or the politics themselves, can follow the substance. That substance is that, according to the Finance Minister of this country, Australia is close to being in a parlous economic state and, should commodity prices fall, Australia is close to having the International Monetary Fund knocking on the door again. Some state of affairs!

Essentially, the issue concerns the pace of adjustment. The Minister for Finance, by advocating the removal of spending programs, is trying to force the Government to respond more quickly to our foreign debt problem. The Treasurer, on the other hand, is moving very slowly. There is absolutely no sense of urgency in this year's Budget-none at all-and it is a very political document. The Finance Minister is concerned about the economics. The Treasurer is obsessed about the politics, as well as being concerned about the economics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leadership.
—In this Budget, the politics have dominated the economics for the very point that the shadow Minister for Defence raises. Senator Walsh is reported as warning:

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, if there is another commodity price slide, the IMF will be knocking on the door again.

How right he is. We ought to note that Senator Walsh is concerned about hearing from the IMF again. I emphasise the word `again'. Has the IMF been knocking on the door already? Basically, by failing to move more boldly in cutting expenditures last week in the Budget, the Government has opted for the easy way out-a very slow pace of adjustment. Indeed, it is only forecasting an improvement from $13.5 billion to $11.5 billion on the current account deficit. There is absolutely no margin for bad luck or mistakes with this type of adjustment. It is, to put it succinctly, an incredibly risky strategy. There is a paragraph in Budget Statement No. 1 that points out the very dangers of delaying the adjustment on the external account-one of the few in this carefully crafted Budget Statement No. 1 that gives any sort of a warning about the state of the economy. I quote from page 49 of the document:

On the other hand, the longer the adjustment period, the greater is the build-up in foreign debt and the greater the call on future income to service that debt. Prolonging the adjustment period also means greater vulnerability to further shocks that are adverse to Australia's external performance (for example, a further deterioration in the terms of trade or export demand), and involves a more searching test of the patience of foreign creditors.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's out of context. Why don't you read that in context?

—My, Government members are quick, are they not? I thought that I heard them parroting things being out of context yesterday too. They talk about context; this is it in a nutshell. It is exactly what Senator Walsh and those on this side of the House are worried about. Australia's AAA credit rating has already been downgraded under the Hawke-Keating Government. One would think that that would move the Government to a faster pace. That downgrading was a rational response by the international financial market to our high level of foreign debt and the inadequate pace of adjustment. Both foreign and domestic investors were quite unwilling to finance the binge of private and public consumption expenditures brought about by the Treasurer's first few Budgets. Let me remind the House that the Government's first Budget deficit was $8 billion in 1983-84, followed by another huge deficit in 1984-85. These deficits swallowed Australia's domestic savings and forced us as a nation to borrow overseas and run up a huge foreign debt. The decline in our terms of trade in 1985 was not, as the Government has argued, the cause of our external problems. It only exacerbated an already serious situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister and the Treasurer, evidently because of a lack of political courage-in the words of Senator Walsh-have exposed Australia to the dangers of a continued buildup in our foreign debt. Obviously, if things go wrong-I will cite a few things that could go wrong, and they are hardly exaggerated examples-such as imports rising by more than projected, a disruption to world trade such as illustrated by what the Americans are doing in Congress at the moment, and/or an outbreak of industrial problems in Australia and exports not rising as much as anticipated, a downturn in world economic growth or a fall in commodity prices, we would be in deep economic trouble. Can any member of this House say that any of those cannot occur? No. Each or any number could occur.

In the event of such an adverse outcome, we face two choices: a dramatic turnaround in our economic policy to correct the external balance or, as Senator Walsh has said, intervention by the IMF. We have not raised this spectre; the Minister for Finance has. Both these choices are draconian, to say the least. A dramatic turnaround in economic policy would cause major disruptions in the economy. Obviously this means increased unemployment, increased interest rates, a fall in the exchange rate, increased taxes and sharp cuts in government expenditure. We would, essentially, have to revert to crisis management. Ordinary Australians would be thrown out of work, have their incomes cut and, once again, we would be called upon to tighten our belts. That is a great way to manage the economy, is it not? Why not take more decisive measures now, as we have said and as Senator Walsh advocates? After all, we would be in a position, if those events occurred, to weather the storm.

As to the second alternative, if the International Monetary Fund intervenes, we really will have reached the bottom of the barrel. The IMF would demand dramatic changes to our economic policy. In effect, the Government would have to yield sovereignty over our economic policy to an international body. Let me remind honourable members that the intervention by the IMF to which Senator Walsh referred is not the same as simply borrowing from the IMF under the compensatory financing facility. Many Australians probably do not realise the indignity of yielding economic control to the IMF. Every three months we would have to report to it our progress in monitoring fiscal and monetary policy. We could be forced to make large changes to wages policy to restore our international competitiveness. In short, we would be joining all those countries, many of which are in the Third World, that have accumulated huge international debts and are in hock to the IMF. Australians do not want that scenario. I am sure that members of this Parliament do not want that scenario. Members of the Government were not elected to allow that scenario to occur. Yet that is the very scenario that the Minister for Finance has drawn to our attention.

Why not put our house in order, as the Opposition has advocated? How can we gain the respect of the international community if we cannot manage our economy properly? In short, Australians want to be able to look after themselves and to be in a position to help others. There is no way we can do this without accelerating the pace of adjustment and reducing the risk of ending up as just another one of the international basket cases. After all, Senator Walsh, no less, said:
A country which has a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country with few options.

Few options, indeed; we simply do not have the luxury of accommodating the short term political desires of the Treasurer. It cannot be said, either, that the remarks made by Senator Walsh on Saturday were simply an aberration. I recited yesterday the sorts of things he pointed to. I recited again today elements that developed further as we heard the tape of Senator Walsh talking about the IMF and other issues and the macro setting not being sufficiently right. It cannot be said that his remarks were an aberration, because on 7 August he raised publicly the issue about making quality cuts, as he expressed it, in government expenditure. He said on this day last month:
We have not been moving as quickly as the externally imposed circumstances demand.

After adjusting for asset sales, the Government has cut outlays in the Budget by only 1.2 per cent in real terms. In June 1983, not long after the election of the Hawke Government, the net foreign debt was approximately $23 billion. By June of this year net foreign debt had nearly quadrupled to $83 billion. That is quite apart from the debt service ratio which has increased dramatically. We are now putting aside approximately 19 per cent of earnings from exports of goods and services just to service our debt, and the situation will not get much better in this financial year. We will continue, as the House knows, to accumulate net foreign debt at about the rate of $1 billion per month.

In conclusion, apart from the reference to the IMF, Senator Walsh also drew the analogy with Argentina. Let me quote from this interesting book Australia and Argentina: on Parallel Paths written by Tim Duncan and John Fogarty. At pages 162 and 164 they state:

Stagnation is a dreadful experience. Argentina is one of the few products of the Industrial Revolution to have suffered it, and it is perhaps the only modern society to have converted itself from an optimistic community of European immigrants to a Third World country during the life of a generation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that in all speeches of this kind there has to be some tiny element of truth. Of course, that element was quite evident when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), said of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that he was not seeking the leadership of his Party. That is thoroughly appropriate coming from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition because the same certainly cannot be said of him. I will say this for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition: I think he is regarded with some benign good humour amongst the broader electorate and remembered with some affection for his role as Minister for Foreign Affairs. But since that day, in his new role as Deputy Leader of the Opposition, everybody realises that, although he might pontificate and try to sound like a shadow Treasurer, basically he is a deputy leader who somewhat reluctantly sheaths his stiletto while he waits for his Leader to stumble and fall.
—Come on! Get with it.

—I am happy to get on with it. I will say this for the honourable gentleman: I give him 10 out of 10 for gall. There he was, standing in here bleating about this Government putting the economy at risk. He was part of the previous Government. Let us look at the record of this bunch of failures opposite. We are told that we must not mention the record of these men opposite who now talk at a time when the average Australian is looking forward to some hope of economic prosperity as the result of work done by this Government and this Treasurer (Mr Keating). We must not remind these honourable gentlemen opposite of the situation that was inherited by the Hawke Government when it came to office. Let us recall it.

SPEECH.PARA: When we came to power in March 1983 inflation was running at 11.5 per cent a year. Economic growth was but a fond memory, and over the financial year 1982-83 the economy had actually contracted. Ten per cent of the work force was unemployed. The prospective Budget deficit had blown out to a massive $9.6 billion. Industrial disputes were at an all time high. Company profits had fallen to historically low levels choking off investment spending. A huge rise had taken place in unit labour costs, and an overvalued dollar was causing devastation to our whole manufacturing industry. That is the record of the failed Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is now Leader of the Opposition. It is no wonder the honourable gentlemen opposite want to leave this chamber. They do not like to be reminded of the situation that this Government found itself in when it came to office. Do not let any of the honourable gentlemen opposite, Mr Deputy Speaker, have the gall or the political dishonesty to walk in here and talk about placing the economy at risk.

With a coherent economic policy and being prepared to face up to and take the hard decisions, it took years for this Government to sort out the economic mess that we inherited from honourable gentlemen opposite. The decisions that were made were not easy. We made the decision to impose an assets test. We made the decision to impose a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax. Every one of those hard decisions was opposed by the honourable gentlemen opposite although they knew that these measures were the only way in which we could bring back some measure of equity and justice into our taxation system. Day after day in this Parliament they warned the Government that these measures, taken together or singly, would bring it down. That was their position.

When we went into the last election, what was their promise? What was their economic strategy 10 weeks ago? Where would Australia have been, where would the average Australian family have been if we had listened to the snake oil policies put forward by the Leader of the Opposition? We can all remember them. The Opposition's position was simple. It said, `Don't worry about the balance of payments. Don't worry about the economy; we'll give you tax cuts-a fistful of dollars'. And how was it going to be paid for? Ten weeks ago the honourable gentleman opposite, who talked about the economy being in jeopardy, said that we could have tax cuts. And how were they going to be paid for? They were to be achieved by massive cuts. Then, of course, it was quite improper for anybody to suggest this. Not only did members of the Opposition get their figures wrong but also we were not to ask them where the cuts were going to be made because that might cause some unhappiness in the community.

Do we not remember the Leader of the Opposition going on television and radio saying, `In the first week of a Howard government, we will sit there and make cuts right across the board. Don't ask us exactly where'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Senator Walsh.

—I will come to Senator Walsh, do not worry about that. At this stage, I want to remind the Opposition of its fiscal record. There is not a honourable member on that side of the House who can stand up in this House and talk with any degree of political or economic credibility about the recent Budget, because the reality is that the Treasurer produced a Budget which, for the first time, virtually, was balanced.
—He cooked the books.
—He cooked the books.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting, as will the honourable member for Moreton.
—I do not mind members opposite bleating. Bleat they may well.
—It is not up to the Minister to mind, it is up to the Chair.

—I am indebted to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let me remind the House that we have waited with some patience, because the Budget has now progressed some distance. I would have hoped and thought that if the Opposition were so concerned about the Budget package, we would have heard, either from the Leader of the Opposition or from some of the so-called fiscal spokesmen-I do not blame the honourable member opposite because nobody regards him as a fiscal spokesman-of an alternative economic strategy. Where is it?

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition gets terribly excited. It is an Opposition that lives off headlines. It picks up the paper on Monday and, goodness me, Senator Walsh said something at the Labor Party conference and Opposition members come in here and live off it for a couple of days on the basis that it is a substitute for their economic policy. Does anybody recall the alternative economic statements that could have been made by the Leader of the Opposition? This was an opportunity, if the Opposition believes that these cuts can be made, for it to tell us where and in which area they can be made.

I will say this for Senator Walsh: like any Minister for Finance, he makes every Minister in this Government justify every line of expenditure. He has had many wins and he has had a few losses, which is what one can expect from a responsible Minister for Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the IMF?

—Let us talk about all of those things. What is the basic attitude of an opposition without credibility and without a coherent economic policy? I will say this for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition: he has said that he will take the Opposition's taxation policies in another direction. He has not told us which direction, but it will be another direction. He is trying to move away from the lamentable policies that were adopted-the stay cool economic remedies of his Leader in the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the Budget produced by the Treasurer has-this Government has consistently argued this-allowed Australia to embark on a long-term process of economic reconstruction and progress. That had to be done in 1983 and accelerated in the wake of the collapse of our terms of trade in 1985 and 1986. That process has been underpinned by progressive fiscal reform. We have not shirked-not this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), not this Treasurer and not this Minister for Finance. On not one occasion have they shirked telling the Australian people the truth about the nature of our financial problems and about the necessity and urgency to embark upon the task of remedying those problems. Let me quote the words of the Prime Minister in his speech addressed to the Australian Financial Review post-Budget dinner. He said:
. . . tonight I want to comment on the contribution the budget makes to our longer-term task of economic reconstruction, an aspect which can too easily become lost in the post-budget euphoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the road to Argentina.

—I would not want to know what road the honourable member is travelling down, or what road he has been on. The statement made by the Prime Minister is a statement made at a dinner at which he was saying very simply--
—What about a banana republic?
—The honourable member should get back to reading his comics. It is all he is fit for.
—At least he reads them, not just looks at the pictures like you do.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Dawson should be quiet. I warn the honourable member for Dawson.

—The reality of the situation is that there is no way in which the Opposition can interpret that candid and forthright statement by the Prime Minister as doing anything other than saying to the people of Australia through a group, the financial editors, `Look, the Budget has been a remarkable success, but it should not be regarded as a panacea. We cannot afford to be complacent and we cannot resile from the real tasks of economic reconstruction, which were necessary and which had to take place given the failure and problems that we inherited from the Opposition'. What has been the result of the policies adopted by this Government?
—What about Senator Walsh, Argentina and the IMF? You told us you would tell us about him.

—Go and sharpen your stiletto. Johnny is not doing too well. Investment is picking up, especially in plant and equipment and manufacturing. Exports are picking up, especially exports of manufactured goods. Interest rates are falling without undermining confidence in our exchange rate. Our current account deficit is falling and in 1987-88 it will be down 4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). Economic growth is being substantially underpinned by net exports. The Treasurer can be proud of his Budget. The Prime Minister can be proud of his achievements, and the Minister for Finance can be proud of the role that he has played in helping this economic reconstruction.

SPEECH.PARA: I will say this: we can stand on that record and we can go to the people of Australia on that record. The guilty men opposite have no economic philosophy, no economic history and come into this House living desperately off the latest newspaper headline. We reject this motion as being nothing more than a waste of the time of this House, and as not contributing anything to a serious analysis of the economic problems that this Parliament has to face. The Treasurer has produced a Budget of which he can be proud. It is time we had an Opposition in which the Australian people could take perhaps a little measure of pride.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come back to how proud the Treasurer (Mr Keating) can be some aspects of his Budget! The Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding) was true to form with his customary mixture of abuse, smart talk, irrelevance and telescopic memory. I remind him that his side has been in power for the last 4 1/2 years and the problems with which we are coping are of its making. The Minister has not in any way answered the Opposition's matter of public importance, namely, the failure of the Government to take the action reasonably necessary and prudent to reduce the likelihood of Australia going down the Argentinean road. I take this opportunity to complete the quotation that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was prevented from completing, the final paragraph of which was:

SPEECH.PARA: The point of comparing Australia with Argentina is to show that there is another option for the Australian economy which may interest people as much as the splendid visions inspired by Japanese, Scandinavian or North America experience. That option is economic stagnation.

We are confronted with an historic split between the two top economic Ministers in this Hawke Government, and the ultimate losers will be the Australian people and the future of this country. One is a Treasurer, presenting a Budget to which the Minister referred in his concluding remarks as a model, actually a patina of fiscal rectitude and reaping a euphoric market response, and the other is a Minister for Finance showing some responsible consistency, some continuing recognition of the Treasurer's banana republic perception of more than a year ago-has he forgotten all that?-and of the characterisation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at that time of the Australian situation as akin to war. That recognition at that time resulted in a significant thrust of government policy towards encouraging the process of adjustment of the Australian economy in coming to grips with its massive current account deficit imbalance and our vast and relentlessly rising overseas debt.

The Opposition's point, and I suggest Senator Walsh's also, is that that impetus is not maintained in the policy settings and Budget thrust of 1987-88. It should have been maintained. The adjustment process is a continuing process over the foreseeable future. It will be a long haul, as I have often said. Not to maintain the impetus is an abdication of the Government's responsibility to the Australian people. The utter priority is to push the pace of that adjustment as rapidly as possible lest, hostage to the rest of the world as we are, conditions in the world economy change-commodity prices stop rising, the ready flow of money from abroad to finance our excessive national spending abates and we are left exposed and vulnerable to economic disaster and, as a last resort, the administrations of the International Monetary Fund.

Let me state once again the nature of the difficult, not to say the perilous situation this country is in which was so played down by the Treasurer in the Budget Speech. The central economic issue confronting the nation is the persistent massive current account deficit, our spending more on imports and interest on debt than we are earning in exports. We are living beyond our national means, putting this nation further into hock by the order of $30m to $50m every day. I say to the Australian people that from this time yesterday to this time today we have run up an extra overseas bill of $30m to $50m.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder Walsh is upset.

—It is no wonder. He can see the difficulty. We pay for that by borrowing overseas in one form or another, thereby adding relentlessly to our vast overseas debt. At the same time inflation is still at 9 per cent, way above that of our trading partners, unemployment is over 8 per cent and new business investment is at the lowest level for many years, compounding our exposure and vulnerability. That situation is unsustainable. The essential strategy to meet the situation is to restrain our private spending on every day goods and services and government spending, thus increasing national savings relative to the nation's income and production; to increase productivity and competitiveness; and to push resources into increased investment and production of exports and of Australian goods to replace imports, and in that way to reduce our reliance on foreign borrowings-all as a matter of urgent priority.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, in his Budget Speech, and the Minister Assisting the Treasurer today have focused on the balanced national Budget as underlining that the Government is pulling its belt in as its contribution to the process I have just suggested, of spending less and drawing less on national savings. I do not suggest that there is not a significant improvement in the fiscal, the budgetary situation. But to underline the inadequacy of the Treasurer's and Government's approach, to point up the gloss given to the reality of what has been done, indeed, the patent dishonesty of a whole series of statements and claims in the Treasurer's Budget Speech, let me--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh has blown the cover.

—He has. Let me look at the contribution on the spending side to the achievement of the `balanced' Budget. The Treasurer claimed there was a `2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth spending'; `the biggest cut in the 35 years for which comparable records are available'; and `a cut in outlays of $3,500m'. What is the substance of that? It is all set out in Budget Paper No. 1 at pages 66 to 71. There are two items that hit us in the eye among the hundreds of mainly tiny snippets of spending cuts from forward estimates of expenditure-not actual expenditure. The first is general purpose payments to the States which are cut by $1,000m; $1 billion, a cut in real terms of upwards of 4 per cent, which I would not dispute. When we work it out, Commonwealth spending in real terms on this Government's own activities will actually increase slightly. Just cut payments to the States, that is the easy way. The second-and this is the real gloss and misleading point-is asset sales. Yes, you heard it. The proceeds from asset sales of $1 billion are shown as a negative outlay-for goodness sake! The projected billion dollars of assets sales of such things as Commonwealth land in Tokyo and the ambassadorial residence in Paris make up nearly one-third of the vaunted cut in Commonwealth spending. That may be an international convention but when the sales are of that order in relation to the change in spending, it is nothing other than a tortuous use of language and is patently dishonest to trumpet $3 billion plus of cuts in government outlays.

SPEECH.PARA: In plain terms that the man in the street can understand, the proceeds of the sales are an addition to revenue-albeit their true place in the Budget scene is as a component of the financing of the real deficit, not as a factor conditioning reducing the deficit. The truth is that the Government has fudged the whole thing. Tragically, and I believe Senator Walsh agrees, the Government has passed up the opportunity for some meaningful cutting of excessive government expenditure, thereby passing up the opportunity to push ahead in the absolutely crucial adjustment process to which I have referred. That process is the central issue before us and is hardly addressed. Growth, while we rely on the rest of the world to continue to pick up the tab for our national overspending, our living beyond our means has been put before a more rapid containment of the current account deficit and the debt problem. What this amounts to is that we are about to lose a year in the long haul of containing the current account deficit and our overseas debt, the long haul back from the Argentinean road to a path of sound economic development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from an intellectually bankrupt opposition whose whole argument has been based not on anything which it has been able to conceive of but on supposed reports of comments made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) at a private function. This is the best the Opposition can do in attempting to come to grips with our economic situation. We have heard a lot of comments from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) such as `Australia is about to be overtaken by the International Monetary Fund (IMF)'. Let me tell the Deputy Leader something about this. The only thing the IMF will do in Australia is to learn a lesson from this Government about how to get out of trouble. Since the Budget the stock exchange has soared, interest rates have come down and the general economic situation is brighter than it has been for many years. All the indicators show this.

SPEECH.PARA: What are we told by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition? We are told that there is some problem in that the IMF is about to intervene in Australia. What rubbish! The fact is that the Government has come down with a balanced Budget, for the first time in 17 years, something which was never achieved under seven years of Liberal-National Party Government. What is important about that is that it is having an impact on interest rates and general economic conditions. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition enumerated six points on which he supposedly agrees with Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh made some private comments. Senator Walsh is one person within a government. We in the Australian Labor Party believe in solidarity in government and we believe in a united approach. The united approach came out in the Budget which was presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last week. This Budget was along the right track in a number of directions, but it was along the right track in a number of directions only because we had the courage to reject the approach of the New Right as advocated by our opponents opposite. They were opposed to the very things which allowed us to balance the Budget. They wanted no capital gains tax, no assets test and no fringe benefits tax-they did not want any of the things which allowed for a fiscally responsible situation to be achieved.

Honourable members opposite then come into this House and say, `Well, now that you have achieved this situation we had better find something that is wrong with it'. According to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, we have not cut enough in government spending. How would he know? He would not even know half the programs that exist in the Commonwealth with his experience in these matters. He would not know the impact of programs and program cuts on ordinary people. We in this Government are not Thatcherites. We do not believe in monetarism; we do not believe in cutting government programs simply for the sake of cutting programs irrespective of their social consequences. The social consequences of cutting the kinds of programs which were suggested by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who was rejected by the Australian people because he was going to cut all those programs, would have had a devastating impact in a number of ways-the poor would have become much poorer and the rich would have become much richer. There would have been massive increases in unemployment-the very thing which occurred under the Fraser Government, especially in its last two years in office when it disgracefully threw 300,000 people out of work. Do members of the Opposition think that the return of these sorts of programs which would cut everything in an irresponsible fashion would result in increased employment? Certainly not. It would result in increased unemployment and we would have a similar situation to that in the United Kingdom, of unemployment at disgraceful levels of 12 to 15 per cent as it has been during the period of the Thatcher Government. Those are the kinds of policies which those opposite would put before us.

We have heard a lot of nonsense today about Australia being on the Argentinean road. Does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition know anything about Argentina? Does he know of the substantial differences between the Argentinean economy and the Australian economy? Of course he does not. Does he know of the difference in the social system? We have had a lot of lambasting from the Opposition about a situation which is in no way analogous-Argentina and Australia. This is not to say that there are not problems. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has pointed them out. Of course there are problems, but those problems are being countered in a sensible and responsible fashion. It is easy to suggest a devastating approach to the current account deficit-that is, an approach which brings on a recession; an approach which will devastate the economy and create massive unemployment-just to solve the current account problem. That is what honourable members opposite want. We are not going to give it to them because we are going to undertake an approach which is a sensible one and which will solve that problem without also, at the same time, destroying the social fabric of this country, creating massive unemployment and all those other things.

We are not in any way running away from our responsibilities in relation to the current account deficit. On the contrary, we are putting into place some very important policies which have not even been referred to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the two debates on this issue; namely, industry policies and industry development policies to develop our export industries and to reduce our reliance on imports. In the long term the only way in which we will be able to resolve this problem is through the restructuring of our economy in a sensible and graduated approach.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition tried to make a great deal out of Senator Walsh's speech. The Government's position is clear. The Government has not accepted the representations of Senator Walsh on these matters because we have put into place a philosophy and an approach which work-an approach which is leading us to a very substantial resolution of problems. I say to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), that it is an approach that he will not find in any of the economic text books. The previous approach is based on a very important resolution of the crisis; it is based on co-operation and consensus within the community and not on confrontation of the kind which the honourable member and his Party would bring into this country. Honourable members should look at what happened in the United Kingdom when the approach that they are advocating was put forward. The whole nation was divided; workers were against employers; there was social division; and, as I said before, the poor were getting poorer and the rich were getting richer because of this factious regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is under you.

—The honourable member says, `What are you doing?'. Has he not heard of the poverty package, the package of assistance to families? This is one of the greatest reforms brought forward to assist families in poverty. We brought this forward not only as an election commitment; we brought it forward because we are concerned with the current account deficit and the external problems of the economy. But we are also concerned to ensure a quality of life for our people, a redistribution of wealth and income so we will have a more just society and the resolution of problems through an approach which is humane and which will be able to resolve our crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Opposition had not, years ago, abandoned any attempt to restructure the Australian economy, we would not be in the position that we are in now in relation to that restructuring. But we will achieve this restructuring and we will resolve those problems in a humane way which does not adopt the policies of those opposite.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 September, on motion by Ms Crawford:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
May it please Your Excellency:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Lowe, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —To be permitted by the consensus of the ballot box to serve in the Parliament of a great democracy is at once a very great privilege, an enduring responsibility and also an exciting challenge.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the atmosphere of constantly unfolding human drama which is parliament I hope that, with the aid of my colleagues and the members of my electorate, I may be able to differentiate between the theatre and the realities. I need to remind myself that this great stage, Canberra, its Parliament and its bureaucracies, is not an end in itself but rather a means-an instrument for the betterment and progress of humanity. I see it as our main task to create an optimum environment in which individuals and families are free and able to develop their potentials to pursue the careers of their choice, to seek the endless adventures of mind and body, to explore the arts and to assist the underprivileged while zealously preserving the dignity and the freedom of all.

Democracy is clumsy, noisy, combative, frustrating. It is the eternal despair of those, the electors, who watch and listen to its endless byplays. In Churchill's words, `It is the worst of all systems of government, except for all others'. Of all systems, it best understands the human spirit and best assists the needs and the strivings of the free man and the free woman. In its finest sense, it must seek to provide equality of opportunity for all. There must be no sense of paternalism, no suggestion that the government knows best, no second class citizens. I hope I will never forget these eternal precepts.

I wish to express my thanks to the electors of Lowe for the very great honour they have bestowed on me and to the many voluntary workers who assisted me in the campaign. I acknowledge the work of my predecessor, Michael Maher, in both State and Federal spheres and I wish him well in his future.

I remind myself that the electorate of Lowe derives its name from Robert Lowe, Viscount Sherbrooke, a remarkable Englishman who, in his brief eight years in Australia in the mid-1800s, made a unique contribution to public life and to the nature and character of our future nation. He played an outstanding part in bringing about self-government, in the opening up of land to settlement, in the cessation of convict transportation and in improving the conditions of convicts.

In regard to the improvement of conditions for convicts, it occurred to me that perhaps at the next redistribution we could commemorate the efforts in this regard of a recent New South Wales Minister and rename the electorate `Jackson' but I suspect that it would not be widely popular. Robert Lowe, however, was an untiring reformer. He has set a redoubtable pattern to follow.

The Address-in-Reply debate is the Parliament's response to the address delivered by the Governor-General at the opening of Parliament last Monday week. The address is prepared and written by the government of the day. Its purpose is to project a broad framework of the Government's policies and programs during the life of the Parliament to be fleshed out with later legislation. There are really very few opportunities in the Parliament to study and debate the broad overview; to observe the full orchestration and to analyse the stated priorities. I welcome this opportunity. In so doing I am only too conscious of the massive learning process confronting me. In that, I am a very willing and eager student.

There is for us all, and for each generation, one overriding priority: this is the prevention of any nuclear conflict or any major conventional war which might escalate to attempt nuclear resolution. Against a world history marked in almost every generation by military conflict, our challenge to outlaw war is unprecedented, but nonetheless imperative. There can be no nuclear war which is limited, no winners in a nuclear conflict, no protection for non-combatants or for so-called nuclear free zones. All political parties-indeed all sane individuals in Australia-are anti-nuclear war. They differ only in the methods of achieving the goal, not in the goal itself. I strongly believe that we must upgrade the anti-nuclear debate in quality and factual integrity of argument and in the continuity and prominence of the message.

The current Washington talks on the elimination of all intermediate nuclear force weapons are encouraging. Achievement of this goal would certainly be a useful start. But it needs to be paralleled by significant reductions in the conventional forces in Europe so as to achieve a more equitable balance between the Warsaw Pact forces and the forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation.

High on the priorities of all of us must be the scrupulous preservation of the environment. I hope and trust that our new Minister responsible for the environment learns to appreciate that a wilderness is more than just a parking lot with no white lines marked on it. Some welcome focus is now being directed towards the protection of the world ozone layer in order to resist the dangers of the greenhouse effect-the shrinkage of the polar ice caps, overheating of the earth's atmosphere, the rising of sea levels and the destruction of vegetation. I welcome this, but much more attention both locally and world-wide needs to be given to the prevention of acid rain. This is largely the product of the release of sulphur and nitrogen gases from coal-fired electricity power stations. Acid rain is massively destroying forests, lakes, flora and fauna and is damaging to human health. By contrast, the timber fellers, chainsaw and axe, although important, are puny in their destructive outcome.

We need a broader, more vigorous and long range approach to the conservation of many of the world's resources and of Australia's resources, but particularly the non-renewables. Because oil is now in temporary glut and low priced, the world is again on an oil burning spree, forgetting the lessons of the mid-1970s when there was an oil crisis. It is unmindful of the fact that known reserves are severely limited. In Australia we have failed to conserve and to convert even though our known indigenous supplies of oil are falling sharply and sadly. Exploration too has markedly fallen away.

Our future generations are not going to thank us for our profligacy in resource usage. The world is burning coal in ever-increasing quantities, often very inefficiently, as though it had a never-ending supply. If not for conservation, then surely for good housekeeping we must use our resources more skilfully and more sparingly to keep down our costs.

Domestically the task of government is to ensure satisfactory living standards, the opportunity for jobs and careers of choice and the adequate relief of the underprivileged. Surely no nation or government can remain complacent with an unemployment rate which has established itself at above 8 per cent over the last four years and which is predicted to remain at that chronically high level for the next three years. No country or government can accept as inevitable chronic youth unemployment as high as 20 to 25 per cent with individual periods of unemployment averaging a year and growing. It is demoralising to the individual, inhibiting of valuable talents and destructive of striving and enterprise. With high chronic unemployment human dignity suffers as well as living standards. It is a confession of failure of us all and intolerable in both the short and the long term.

Why are our living standards falling? In simple terms, Australia has been costed out of world markets, not by countries with lower wage structures but by those with higher productivity. `Productivity' is probably the single key word here. Quite clearly, as we have heard so many times today, we are going down the Argentinean road. Incredibly, many of the countries which are out-competing us, such as Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Singapore, have very few if any natural resources of their own. They have to import raw materials from countries such as Australia, often at great cost and over great distances. Yet Australia has everything going for it-an equable climate, adequate land, the capacity for virtually unlimited electric power generation, pretty well every important mineral, an educated work force, and a wage package which is not too appreciably higher than that of our competitors. Also, Australians have shown on many occasions their capacity for initiative, skill and application when the opportunity has been given to them.

Why then are we not competing favourably with the outside world? That is the essential question to be analysed and to be discussed with the whole Australian community. When all Australians fully understand the real nature of the problem and their vital part in resolving it this country will be well on the way to recovery.

For far too long we have pretended that governments can remedy things, given a mandate. The truth is that it is the people who must determine the level of Australia's productivity. For them to do so, they must be told the facts. Governments must drastically reduce the burden of taxation, charges and regulations upon industries and individuals.

Industrial disputes must be more flexibly resolved at the work face. Inefficient work practices must go, by mutual consent and understanding. Managerial skills and technology need to be upgraded. Adequate rewards, by means of effective margins for skill, bonuses, profit-sharing and employee shareholding must be developed. What Australia urgently needs right now is a full and frank understanding of the nature of the problems, a clear outline of the task for each one of us-worker, boss, union, government and card subject-and the achievement of co-operation in place of confrontation.

There is a real urgency to set our productivity at a genuinely competitive level. The world's two great industrial giants, the United States of America and Japan, face enormous problems of industrial trade and fiscal readjustment. Those readjustments, which must inevitably follow the presidential elections in the United States next year, may well be sudden and may well be savage. They must severely harm Australia unless we get our house in order beforehand.

We can no longer rely on farming and mining to supply our exports and sustain our living standards. Food and fibres are in oversupply and are likely to remain so. Minerals are in glut; prices are low. Farming and mining are not, and never will be, labour intensive. Countries which rely on them predominantly for export earnings generally have low and declining living standards. The countries with rising living standards and higher employment are those with broad manufacturing and service industries; exactly what Australia must develop. We must strive to expand our manufacturing base. In particular we must process and upgrade our own minerals. There is no point in sending them off to Japan to be transported back here, having been processed. The decline in industrial investment must be arrested and reversed. For many years Australia led the world in major social reforms. Governments of liberal philosophy introduced a wide range of programs aimed at assisting families in health, social welfare, retirement, home ownership and education while preserving the dignity and striving of individuals.

As one who has spent his working life in the health sphere in daily, indeed hourly, contact with people of all ages, of social and economic conditions and with all sorts of personal problems, I am deeply concerned that Australia's health services are rapidly declining in both quality and quantity and that it is the poorer people who are suffering the most. The great teaching hospitals which produce the new generations of health workers are in crisis. They suffer a huge reduction in beds, a major shortage of nurses and the loss, mainly through resignation, of many outstanding specialist physicians and surgeons. Waiting lists for elective surgery are huge and growing. The affluent may go to private hospitals but the poor, who are now second class citizens in the health sense, must join the queue often for a year or more. If the teaching hospitals continue to decline in quality and delivery the whole standard of medicine in Australia will suffer. This whole question is one which needs to be addressed urgently by both Federal and State spheres of government.

In Australia the retention rates at our schools, colleges and universities fall far below those of other countries which compete with us, such as Japan and the United States of America. Prompted no doubt by the lack of job opportunities for early school leavers the year 11 and 12 retention rates are rising, but there is still a long way to go. Adolescence is always a difficult journey. We sometimes underestimate the problems of the young. There is a need in our high schools for more emphasis on pastoral care and counselling. Education must be made to appear more relevant and the students to feel a stronger sense of belonging and meaningful involvement. It must be the duty of government to ensure higher standards in both government and independent school systems. Parents must be encouraged to participate more actively and more meaningfully in the process. In early childhood development, probably the most critical period, the parents must be the prime and the vital educators. We must seek to beckon on, to develop self-competition in each individual, and to encourage the pursuit of excellence. There is an enormous human resource lying latent, waiting to be unlocked. That unlocking brings rewards and happiness to the individual and very great benefits to everyone in the sharing of the products of talent and striving.

Australia is probably one of the most multicultural of nations. My electorate includes people of diverse ethnic groups and is a microcosm of multiculture-and so much the richer for it. In Lowe the main ethnic group is Italian, but alongside the Italians are Greeks, Yugoslavs, Vietnamese, Indians, Chinese, Lebanese and many others. Australia and Australians, particularly in Lowe, are so much the better and so much more mature because of this intermingling of cultures and customs.

Our indigenous Aborigines present for us a great challenge in human understanding and, above all, in the devising of policies which will ensure for them a dignified future. A traditional nomadic people skilled in hunting, foraging and tribal self-defence, their culture-so different from ours-is built on the extended family. Their religions, their rituals, their sacred grounds and artifacts, their dreamtime, are all motivated by the needs and actions of hunter, forager and defender-a purpose in living which the social security systems of our Western civilisation have effectively removed from them, leaving, in most cases, a void. Even in the outstations and homelands they can no longer return to past lifestyles. Western diseases and foodstuffs, alcohol, clothing and money systems have permanently intruded, along with a multitude of support systems. There is much that we can do to restore health, dignity, self-respect and purpose, but the essential starting point lies in sympathetic understanding.
Perhaps that great Roman playwright, Terence, more than 2,000 years ago expressed best the challenge to us all when he said:
I am a man, I count nothing human indifferent to me.

Concern for and involvement in mankind are surely the qualities essential for those in positions of political and social influence, such as those of us privileged to be in this House. Our policies must be directed to that concern but always attuned to the genuine nature of human beings, and above all designed to bring out the very best qualities, talents and dignities of the individual.

For us all it is people, not parliaments or institutions, who are our goal and purpose. People are always so much better than they or we tend to think they are. They respond magnificently if beckoned on and trusted. Australia's future, and the future of its families and individuals, depends vitally upon taking all the people into our confidence, explaining to them the sensible and desirable roles of governments, unions, management and people and seeking the unlocking of talents, initiative and striving. In that way our future lies secure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Petrie, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My time in parliament has commenced with the setting of the stop clock on the wall. My new career begins here and now. This moment, along with my marriage to Catherine Carew, and the birth of our daughter, Elena Carew-Johns, is the proudest moment of my life. Having protested so long to so many of my friends that I would never seek the life of a parliamentarian, here I stand, the member for Petrie. Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for the call, and may I congratulate all of my new colleagues, on both sides of the House on their election to this place. I thank the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), his Cabinet, the Australian Labor Party, including my team in Petrie, and especially the voters of Petrie for sending me here.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spent time before around the Parliament, as a former national organiser for the Australian Labor Party. In the period between 1978 and 1982 I was privileged to be tutored in the art of political organisation by the then National Secretary, David Combe, the then Assistant National Secretary, Ken Bennett, and the current Secretary, Bob McMullan-men for whom I have the highest regard. I have the distinction of being the first full time official of the National Secretariat to enter the Parliament. However, anyone who suggests that I have charted a new path into politics should think again. It did not take me long to realise that as far as the Party was concerned, at that time in opposition, not a great deal happened in Canberra. The great powerhouses of the Party are, and remain, the State machines. Nevertheless, I do observe that there is a cohesiveness and strength in our National Executive that is the envy of the conservative parties.

It was Combe the entrepreneur and Bennett the organiser who ultimately guided me to this place as the forum which by its very nature turns ideas into practice. I hope that I have chosen wisely in coming here, in supposing that this is a place of influence. Colleagues, I know that with your help I will not be disappointed. I have always been fascinated by the different ways by which individuals arrive here. For some the journey is relatively easy, but for others it is a grinding and even debilitating path. My ride was relatively gentle, a mere 15 years after joining the Party in 1972-only months before Whitlam scored his historic victory. It should never be forgotten that without Whitlam there would be no Hawke Labor Government. Only the hard lessons of 1972 to 1975 could have prepared us for the mantle of incumbency-a mantle which we now wear so comfortably, and which we shall wear for many years to come.

My education in economics and geography at Monash University in the early 1970s took place at a very turbulent time in the nation's affairs. When I first entered the Faculty of Economics I was asked why I chose the course. My answer was simple, `When I read the morning papers I want to understand what is going on in the world'. No longer the angry young man of the 1970s, the chip worn from my shoulder, I have come to an understanding of what is going on. Whilst no longer the idealist, neither am I the cynic.

I cannot say what the `Class of 87' will achieve or indeed what I shall achieve. Whether it is to be a short brutish existence or a long and eventful stay, I cannot predict. I wonder how my mother and father now feel as they sit in the gallery. My father, who was born in 1902 in Tatyoona in western central Victoria, a third generation Australian, has told me of his humble beginnings; of he and his brothers living in a hut with a dirt floor, who, like young pups on a cold winter's morn, would huddle against the outside wall of the hut to catch the warmth of the sun. They would ride from Tatyoona, and later from Willaura, into New South Wales to sell rabbit skins, or at least I suppose until myxomatosis killed the trade. Then in the 1930s, Claude, like so many young men of the time, moved to the city, to Melbourne. It was there that he met an extremely young and attractive woman, Doris Thompson. She was born in a house in Kensington, a single-fronted working man's cottage, where later she and Claude were to make a home. Four sons followed, though not in quick succession: Raymond, Kenneth, Neil and me.

It was only after leaving home and starting my own family that I appreciated the trials and joys that mum and dad must have faced in bringing up their sons. I well remember walking around the streets at home on a Saturday or Sunday, and hearing that characteristic whistle of Claude as he painted yet another roof in Kensington. And as Claude was having a break from his labours with a beer on Sunday morning, jealously guarding the roast cooking in the oven, mum would be at church. I think Doris must have guided nearly a dozen vicars through the Holy Trinity Church and she was, and remains, a stalwart of that church. I might say to you now, mum, that in me you have a son who, although rejecting organised religion, has nevertheless learned its key lesson. I do show concern for my fellow human beings. I thank you and all of my family for your love, your closeness and your support. While none of us can know the future, we can surely work for its creation.

And so to Petrie, and what of its future? Petrie is an electorate characterised by one of the highest levels of Australian born citizens in the country. It is geographically divided between the northern suburbs of Brisbane and the Redcliffe Peninsula and is dissected by the Pine River. It is the Pine River, running as it does across the divisions of Fisher, Petrie and Lilley, joining Hays Inlet at the mouth of Bramble Bay and set within the larger Moreton Bay, with the great Moreton Island lying just off the coast, that is my primary concern today. The mouth of the Pine River, an area of great beauty and great environmental significance, is a wetland area; a living environment for rare native birds and migrating birds from the Northern Hemisphere, for the breeding of fish, and a recreation place for thousands of amateur fishermen and boating enthusiasts.

The future of this region is in the balance. In some ways the future of Pine River holds the key to the future of northern Brisbane itself. Is it to become another Gold Coast, filled with the Hollywood hype, white-shoe brigade, in their glittery living coffins of concrete and glass? Or is it to remain an area for all the people, in its natural state, accessible to those who take the trouble to look, but also accessible in the minds of those who might not seek, but have the comfort of knowing, that a wilderness lies at their doorsteps?

The threat comes from a proposal by Ariadne Australia Ltd which wishes to put a $300m, 7,500-inhabitant canal estate on the southern edge of the river. Ariadne's claim is that the estuarine environment of the river will be preserved. I object to the canal estate, not only on the grounds of environmental damage, but also on the grounds that waterways are for everyone. They are not to be privatised. The company's own plans clearly show that an entire stand of mangroves, and the associated wetland region behind it, will be torn away, cut, drained or filled, to allow for a land use of no productive significance whatsoever.

When I was first taken to the area by local ornithologist Roy Sonnenburg, and shown the birds that nest, wade and feed there, I had to pinch myself to be sure that I had not somehow been transported by the magic of television to the Northern Territory and Kakadu. There were the jabiru nesting, the brolga feeding and the ibis, egrets and royal spoonbill wading. It is a pity that I cannot adequately show photos of these beautiful birds of the Pine River, or indeed even a map of the region, but unfortunately the Standing Orders of the House do not allow me to do justice to this environmental topic.

To digress for a moment from my subject, and with great respect to the Speaker and the Clerks who have guided me in this matter, it is sad that the current Standing Orders, which of course are the product of the members of the House, do not allow for the adequate presentation of material. The means of presenting material in this place reminds me of the great cricket broadcaster, Alan McGilvray, who translated the 1938 tests from England from the London cables and gave to his Australian radio audience a description of play by tapping his pencil on the desk in his Sydney studio to represent bat on ball. It is time that our Standing Orders moved beyond the 1930s. McGilvray wrote. `The game is not the same'. However, I seek permission to table certain photographs of some of the most beautiful and rare birds of this region, namely, the jabiru, the brolga and the royal spoonbill, and two maps of the Brisbane region. One indicates the area covered by the Ariadne proposal and the other is the City of Brisbane Town Plan, statement of intent, which has the same area zoned as `non-urban fabric'. I seek leave to table the documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The area directly under threat by the developer contains substantial stands of mangroves and casuarinas, eucalypts and melaleucas, interspersed between freshwater swamps, salt marshes and tidal mudflats. It is not the classic beauty spot for the picnicker-mangroves are not particularly hospitable places. It is the sort of place where one might find David Attenborough squelching around in his gumboots, looking into the eye of the camera. But the environmental importance of such wetlands is simply not appreciated by the Brisbane City Council or the Queensland State Government. I am trying desperately to find a Federal handle on this issue, so that my Government, with its magnificent record of environmental protection, might come to the rescue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ariadne proposal was knocked back by the Labor City Council in 1985, but the current Liberal Administration turned a blind eye and let the proposal slide through to the State Minister with little adverse comment. So far as I know, the matter is before the Minister responsible for local government, for rezoning and ministerial approval. This is the sort of socialist intervention encouraged in Queensland-socialism for the few.

So far as we are aware, Ariadne has systematically gained control of both leasehold and freehold land in the area and is seeking a slice of crown land as well. The area under threat covers some 500 hectares. The areas adjoining, that is, Hays Inlet and Kippa Ring, are habitat reserves under the State Fisheries Act. They are protected as areas of importance to fisheries. The two regions are contiguous; to encroach upon one might affect the other. In general terms, mangroves are protected by the Fisheries Act but, as explained to me by an official of the Department of Primary Industries, whether or not there is a reserve in the area, if the Minister wants a rezoning, the Minister gets a rezoning.

Mangroves have all too often been assessed in terms of cheap real estate, to be `developed' by reclamation into desirable waterfront property. We now know that mangroves, and their associated wetlands, play an important role in the healthy functioning of an estuary. They act as a nursery area for juvenile fish, help stop erosion of the shoreline, and produce a large amount of organic matter used in the food web of the estuary. The destruction of the mangroves is known to reduce the supply of material to the food system, and rapidly leads to the destruction of the estuarine ecosystem, and consequently the loss of fish.

Both the Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation and the Queensland Sport and Recreational Fishing Council are totally opposed to this and other projects that destroy fish habitat. The Commercial Fishermen's Organisation claims that the Moreton Bay region is the third richest pocket fishery in the world, providing an estimated $80m feedout each year. It is clear that almost all forms of commercially fished marine life-fish, prawns, sand crabs, and the famous Queensland mud crab-spend part of their life cycle in the tidal mudflats. The mangroves also act as an important pollution buffer to Moreton Bay.

In Lane's 1987 definitive edition of Shorebirds in Australia, Moreton Bay is noted as one of the key areas for shorebirds in southern Queensland. The point is reiterated that the coastal wetlands of southern Queensland have either been destroyed or are rapidly being destroyed and that there is insufficient information even to assess the impact of such destruction of shorebirds. Indeed, if the destruction of mangroves is barely justified in the case of productive operations such as the Brisbane Airport, and the various oil refineries, it is totally unjustified for housing. The one study of the wetlands of southern Queensland was undertaken by consultants to the State Government in 1975. Gutteridge, Haskins and Davey recommended the protection of almost all of the remaining mangroves, salt marshes and sea grass beds in southern Queensland. The canal estate is the most greedy, shortsighted and disastrous use of coastal resources.

The Pine River area needs protection, and the best way to achieve that is for a moratorium on the destruction of any and all mangroves in Queensland, just as the enlightened New South Wales Government has done in that State. Not only do the mangroves have to be saved, however, but so must the adjoining tidal and wetland habitats. Any management plan for the Pine River, which must include the reserves of Hays Inlet and Kippa Ring, must protect the associated habitats of the mangrove. In fact, the recommended terrestrial buffer zone is at least 200 metres wide, which means that the Ariadne proposal, or any variation of it, would be absolutely out of the question.

The Queensland Government is not known for its record of environment protection, and the fact that the authority for the protection of mangrove ecosystems is vested in three Ministers-those with responsibility for Lands, Harbours and Marine, and Primary Industries-means that no one person takes responsibility. Whilst the Queenslanders have been sensible enough to put aside some reserves, they keep their options open as it suits them. The hit or miss attitude of the Queensland Government is testified to in that it is the only State to fail to nominate wetlands of international importance to the Ramsar Convention-the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation agreement on the preservation of wetlands of international importance.

While I am not suggesting that Pine River is a subject of international importance, Queensland's refusal to co-operate on the international convention, a most successful convention in Australia, does not leave one with a feeling of confidence that the less significant, but still mightily important areas, will be saved. But perhaps I do have a Federal handle on this issue. The Commonwealth has certain responsibilities under the Japan-Australia Treaty, the Agreement for the Protection of Migratory Birds and Birds in Danger of Extinction and their Environment, and, indeed, under the soon-to-be-ratified Australia-China Treaty. Under article VI of the Agreement each government shall:

. . . endeavour to take appropriate measures to preserve and enhance the environment of birds protected under the provisions of this agreement . . . in particular, it shall seek means to prevent damage to such birds and their environment.

The China Agreement makes similar provisions under article IV. No fewer than 22 different species of migratory bird listed under these agreements feed on the Pine River wetlands, including the mongolian sand plover, Lathams snipe, and the fork-tailed swift. Although Pine River may not be an exclusive feeding ground for these birds, the destruction of the habitat at Pine River would be one more blow to their survival. My earnest hope is that the Federal and State Ministers could meet at the next Council of Nature Conservation Ministers and determine a strategy whereby the entire Pine River, Kippa Ring and Hays Inlet region could be preserved for all time. (Extension of time granted) I thank the Leader of the House (Mr Young). The record of the Queensland Government on environmental matters, in comparison with that of the Federal Government, is like comparing my father's birth place to the new Parliament House. It is indeed remarkably humble.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been enormous wastage from the Services in the last few years-in fact, 25,000 in the last three years. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) referred to those losses as being good for morale. That is a disastrous start for a new Minister. I see that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) is leaving the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall listen.
