SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the defence service home loan changes which the Government proposed in the Budget are one hell of a mess. They are causing great problems in an already debilitated Defence Force. Defence was barely mentioned in the address. It was not mentioned at all in the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). That is understandable from a government point of view. The fact is that our defence capacity is declining. The conditions of service for our service men and women have deteriorated remarkably. The White Paper announced so proudly six months ago is veering off the rails. It is no wonder that the Government does not want any great mention of defence.

It seems to me that the Defence Ministers are currently standing on the edge of a precipice. Mr Beazley, who I suppose is referred to, in these difficult days when one tries to decide who is responsible, as the senior Minister, seems to be gazing out across the valley to the mountains beyond, while the ground is crumbling beneath his feet. The ground to which I refer is the sinews of the defence forces-the men and women who constitute their personnel. Unless the Minister forgets some of those lofty and academic views that he has discovered and comes to grips with the fundamental problems which are affecting this country's defence forces, he will find, in a very short space of time, that he is the owner of some very good defence equipment all of which is quietly rusting away because there is no one with sufficient experience to man it. I urge the Minister to come to grips with the fundamental problems that threaten the capacity of our defence forces. I urge him, for a start, to come to grips with the defence service home loans issue, to which I referred a moment ago and which has caused so much unrest throughout the Services in the few days since the Budget.

It must not be thought that we on this side of the House are in total disagreement with everything the Government does from a defence point of view. That would be very wrong. We are very conscious of the fact that what we are talking about is the security of our country. We agree with the broad strategy as outlined in the Government's defence White Paper. Thank God that it is somewhat different from the paper brought forward by Paul Dibb, which is known as the Dibb report on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities.

We have to thank the chiefs of the various Services and their advisers for taking the Dibb report, massaging it and presenting it as a worthwhile defence document. That is not being totally critical of Mr Dibb. I think that we owe him some gratitude for at least coming to grips with some of the problems that successive governments have dodged over the years. But it should not go unnoticed that, when the Dibb report was produced, the Minister for Defence was totally supportive of it. Yet within a few months he has done a double back flip and has said that the White Paper shows us the way to go. We are very grateful that he saw some sense in that.

We agree, for example, with the concept of a two-ocean Navy, the planning and the establishment of bases for which is now under way. That will be achieved over a long number of years. We agree with the emphasis that has been placed on the north. Perhaps we would differ on the pace of development in those two projects. The big question on the White Paper is: can its proposals be funded? The paper is based on a real annual growth rate of 3 per cent. The Minister for Defence said to the Fabian Society in August 1986:
The Dibb review points the way. Paul Dibb has used a planning figure of 3 per cent real growth. That is no magic figure.

The Minister assured Australians that the proposals would be achieved on a 3 per cent real growth rate. The reality is that the 1986-87 Budget granted an increase of only one per cent in defence expenditure. In the 1987-88 Budget-the Budget just brought down-total defence expenditure is $11m less than that allocated in the previous year. The Government, by some cunning arithmetic and the use of price deflators and so on, says that the figure represents a decline of one per cent. The real facts are that there is a decline in defence spending of something approaching 6 to 7 per cent this year. The Minister now talks not about a 3 per cent growth but about the necessity for long term planning. The promise of 3 per cent real growth has disappeared.

One of the points of very serious disagreement that we have with the Government on defence matters is that we reject totally the no-threat scenario that it tries to comfortably massage and present to the Australian people. We live in a difficult world and in a difficult part of the world. If one thing is sure in defence matters it is that the unexpected will occur. I refer to the problems in the Philippines, the recent problems in Fiji, those in Papua New Guinea-we may have to assist there-Vanuatu, New Caledonia and South East Asia. We have an increasing Russian and Libyan threat in this part of the world. We have lost our influence, to a large extent, in South East Asia and in the Pacific.

Worse than that, we have lost pride in our defence forces. That attitude was engendered by the Australian Labor Party (ALP) during the Vietnam war and immediately after it. Since that criticism and denigration of the Services, they have never been restored fully to their proper place in the Australian community. We intend to make sure that the Services are restored to their proper place and that pride in the Australian defence forces is restored. To bear arms in the defence of one's country should be regarded as a matter of great pride, and not as some sections of the ALP would have it, particularly people such as Dr Cairns who, when he was in government, entertained Vietnamese in this country while our troops were still serving in Vietnam. We intend to restore that pride.

The biggest problem facing the defence forces is that of manpower-the huge wastage and losses that they are suffering. In three years 25,000, over a total base of 70,000, have left the forces; that is, 36 per cent. There is not only enormous wastage in terms of re-postings, with the turbulence that that causes, but also an enormous loss of experience. When people who have gained some experience leave the Defence Force, enormous costs are involved in retraining replacements. The 20-year average loss of pilots from the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) has been about 40 a year. Last year the figure was over 100. Technicians in the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) are in desperately short supply, as are Army signals personnel. The average loss of male officers in the Services has been about 500 a year. In 1986, 800 officers left.

An RAN officer retention survey carried out between November 1986 and March 1987 showed that 88 per cent of those surveyed believed that the erosion of benefits was wrong, was affecting them, and they were considering resigning. The problem is that 80 to 83 per cent of those leaving the Services are leaving before the 20-year period expires. In other words, they have enough experience to be valuable but they are leaving well before they have to do so. All the advice from the service chiefs to the Minister is that this is having a debilitating effect on the Services. A recent report by the Department of Defence to the Minister says:
Positive action to redress the high wastage rate needs to be taken on economic and operational capability grounds.

Yet the newly appointed Minister for Defence says that it is good for morale, when the service chiefs are out there day after day ramming home to the Government the message that the Services cannot withstand these losses, this wastage and this cost of retraining. Mrs Kelly says, `It's good for morale, you fellas, and you had better get used to it'. It is no wonder the Services have problems.

Let me deal briefly with some of the costs that are involved, Apart from the lack of experience. By the time a pilot in the RAAF gets to his first squadron, the cost to train him amounts to $2m. By the time he has done about 1,000 hours and is becoming a very useful pilot, the cost is about $6m. Last year we lost over 100. To train an Army recruit to a basic level costs about $9,000 a year. On top of all this, in the Budget last week the Army is to be reduced by about another 730 personnel, and the Navy and Air Force by 100-odd each. This will cause increasing posting turbulence as the Services desperately try to plug the gaps that the Government has decreed will now be vacant. It will extend the average working week of the service men and women. It is already between 52 and 55 hours, and the Government is going to ask more from those people who are left. Mrs Kelly says that all this wastage is very good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a long way from Crosshouse, a small coal mining town in Ayrshire, Scotland, to Capital Hill, Canberra. While there may appear to be no link between two so vastly different communities, the destinies of both Crosshouse and Canberra have been touched by a remarkable man, a man who served on three separate occasions as this nation's leader; a man whose name is now immortalised by the seat it is my honour to represent.

SPEECH.PARA: The division of Fisher bears the name of Andrew Fisher, Prime Minister of Australia, High Commissioner to England, founding father of the Australian Labor Party. Andrew Fisher's life story is one of achievement; achievement of human will over considerable hardship. It is a case study of how reason, logical argument and common sense will often prevail against those who choose emotion, fear and the irrational as the basis for argument.

Fisher was born in Crosshouse, Scotland, in 1862. A son of a coal miner, he followed his father into the pits at the age of 10. Needless to say, mining was a hard life and the conditions endured by the miners were to leave a lifelong impression on Fisher. Despite the difficulties, Fisher managed to educate himself by attending night school. He became involved at an early age in union activities, and by the age of 17 had risen to become Secretary of the Ayrshire Miners Union.

In 1881, the union called a strike which lasted 10 weeks. It proved disastrous and the union was crushed. For his part, Fisher was blacklisted by the victorious mine owners. The ban rendered Fisher almost destitute. For four years, he struggled to gain work of any sort. There is no doubt the experience convinced Fisher that the future of the labour movement was in direct political involvement.

When it became clear that he had no future in Britain, he emigrated to Australia and settled in the Gympie district of Queensland where he gained work in the gold mines. As in his native Scotland, Fisher became involved in the trade union movement and the fledgling Australian Labour Federation, the forerunner of the Labor Party.

Some eight years after his arrival in Australia, Fisher was elected to the Queensland Legislative Assembly as a Labor member. Like now, Queensland was governed by a conservative squattocracy. One of the prime aims of the Queensland Government was to limit the influence of the trade unions and to ensure industrial harmony by prohibiting strikes and gaoling unionists. To this end, the Government passed the Peace Preservation Act which could be the model for the current industrial legislation of the Bjelke-Petersen regime. Needless to say, the Act was unsuccessful and was subsequently repealed by the Labor governments which dominated the State in the first half of this century.

In contrast, confrontation was not Fisher's way. Despite the hardships of his early life, he did not embrace theories of class warfare. Instead, he sought practical means of improving the lot of working people by legislation on safety standards, workers compensation and minimum wage levels.

In 1889, Fisher became a Minister in the Dawson Queensland Labor Government, which although it lasted only seven days, was the first Labor Government in the world. At the same time, the States were considering their stance on the question of federation. Fisher campaigned hard to convince firstly the Labor Party and then the general public of the value of nationhood. When elections were held for the first Australian Parliament, he successfully nominated for the seat of Wide Bay.

In the following 14 years, he was to be involved in decisions which still affect the lives of millions of Australians. In a number of ways, the issues facing Australia in the years immediately after Federation parallel the issues today. In both instances, government was called upon to decide fundamental issues of the structure of government and its role in the economy. It is an interesting, and-I believe-a worthwhile exercise to reflect upon the choices and decisions made by Andrew Fisher and the Labor governments prior to the First World War. Of the decisions made, the most enduring were in the fields of social welfare and public enterprises. In the area of social welfare, the Fisher Government of 1910-13 can be credited with the establishment of the basic assistance measures of the old age pension, maternity allowance and the invalid pension. However, the measures were not as extensive as Fisher would have liked. In his speech in support of the Invalid and Old Age Pension Bill, Fisher told the House:

Our Bill is not so liberal as I should like to see it. It is only because we are trammelled by financial obligations and tied by the dead hand of the Constitution that I am prepared to accept the Bill.
It all sounds too familiar.

If privatisation is an issue today, then it was the Fisher Government which put public ownership on the long term political agenda. In November 1911, the Parliament passed the Commonwealth Bank Bill. Although King O'Malley received much of the credit for the establishment of the bank, there is no doubt that Fisher, as Prime Minister and Treasurer, played a critical role in the Bill's drafting and passage through Parliament. The bank's savings business opened in July 1912 with agencies in all post offices. The first savings account was that of Andrew Fisher. The trading bank opened in January 1913, when it took over the Commonwealth Government's accounts. Its only capital was a Treasury loan of #10,000 which it soon repaid.

Unfortunately, the same success was not achieved in the area of constitutional reform. Fisher considered the Constitution, although drafted only two decades prior to his Government coming to power, to be a `dead hand' on a reformist government. He believed that constitutional reform should be an ongoing process and, when speaking to the Invalid and Old Age Pensions Bill, said:
Happily the Constitution is so framed that it may be amended by the people from time to time in order that it may keep step with their intelligence and enlightenment.

For Fisher, however, amendment proved far from `happy'. In 1911, soon after his Government was swept to power with substantial majorities in both Houses, he proposed a referendum to extend the Commonwealth's powers over trade and commerce, control of corporations and monopolies and labour and employment, including wages conditions and the settling of disputes. The proposal was defeated, with only Western Australia voting in favour. Undeterred, he again submitted the proposals, this time separated into six questions at the time of the 1913 election. Again, the proposals were defeated, but by a much smaller margin. However, the negative vote contributed to the defeat of Labor at the poll by one seat. Although he was returned as Prime Minister soon after the outbreak of World War I, he was unable to produce the march of legislation of the period of 1910-13. Notwithstanding the failure in constitutional reform and the restrictive interpretations given by the High Court of Australia to Commonwealth Government powers, the Fisher Government set much of the policy framework which dictated the scope of decision-making in following years.

Like the Fisher Labor Government, the Hawke Labor Government finds itself at a time of debate on fundamental issues in the areas of constitutional reform, the structure of government, and the role of government in the economic process. In December 1985, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) appointed members of the public to a commission to examine, review and make recommendations on the Australian Constitution. The Commission replaced the Constitutional Conventions which had been first instituted by the Whitlam Government in 1973. I fully support the cause of a modernised Australian Constitution which, as Andrew Fisher indicated, must be amended to keep step with changed circumstances. If Fisher thought the Constitution was a `dead hand' in 1908, there is no doubt that, 80 years later, it acts in many instances against the interests of the nation it was framed to serve.

The scope of amendments required and the issues canvassed by the several advisory committees reporting to the Commission are too extensive for me to examine now. However, there is one area on which I wish to comment. Recently, the Advisory Committee on the Distribution of Powers reported to Sir Maurice Byers, the Chairman of the Constitutional Commission. The charter of the Committee was to report on the appropriate distribution of powers between the Commonwealth, States, Territories and local government. Chapter 7 of the Committee's report concerns constitutional recognition of local government. The recommendation of the Committee is that local government should not be accorded recognition in the Constitution.

The basis of this recommendation appears to be that constitutional recognition would impose upon the States and the Commonwealth a level of commitment which is not currently displayed. In particular, if the submissions of the then Department of Local Government and Administrative Service together with the Australian Council of Local Government Associations were accepted, it would require this Government and the governments of the States, first, to guarantee a system of local government in the States and Territories; secondly, to protect councils from arbitrary dismissal; thirdly, to invalidate laws which impair the capacity of local authorities to function; and finally to entitle councils to protection from the exercise of Commonwealth and State power to the same extent that the States are protected from the exercise of power by the Commonwealth. In short, local government would become, at least constitutionally, a genuine third level of government. The implication of this is that the distribution of power between governments would, over time, alter substantially as local government would assume an increased role in service provision in areas which have traditionally been the province of the States. The committee was unwilling to recommend such a change.

In contrast, the Advisory Committee on Trade and National Economic Management came to the conclusion that local government should enjoy constitutional recognition. In doing so, the Committee acknowledged that local government was a firmly established tier of government which provided essential services and facilities for the public at local level. While it accepted the desirability of constitutional recognition, the Committee did not recommend the form which the provision should take to extend the recognition. The two conflicting conclusions must place the Commission in somewhat of a dilemma. The recommendations it will make will, in my opinion, have in the longer term a very profound effect on the structure of government in this country.

I am an unabashed supporter of local government. My experience of the system is a practical one, based on my service as a councillor on the Pine Rivers Shire Council, one of Queensland's largest, from March 1982 until last month. In Queensland, local government has enjoyed an excellent legislative framework developed essentially in the period between the two world wars. However, its effective operation has been hampered by a State government bent on ignoring local councils and imposing its own political will, especially in town planning matters. Two clear examples involved the use of ministerial rezonings to approve developments contrary to the provisions of the Brisbane City Town Plan. The first allowed the construction of the so-called `world's tallest building' which in the vein of the `Big Cow', `Big Pineapple' and Big Russ, continues Queensland's fixation on the oversized. The second allowed the establishment of the ill-fated Imperial Chemical Industries (ICI) Australia chemical plant at Lytton. In both cases, the wishes of the public-not to mention the set procedures involved in the Brisbane Town Plan-were overriden without right of appeal in any form.

The number of occasions on which the Queensland Minister for Local Government has by-passed local town plans by way of ministerial rezonings has increased at an extraordinary rate in the last year. On all occasions, the rights of residents of a local community to appeal are removed. The ability of the local authority to impose even the most basic conditions on the development is also removed. The situation in Queensland demonstrates the paradox of local government. The States and the Commonwealth have over time handed over to local authorities a range of responsibilities which at the same time give the councils powers which the State governments are unwilling to let the councils use.

There needs to be a careful appraisal of the distribution of government power in this country. I believe that a more regionally-orientated local government system, given a suitable legislative framework and financial security, can deliver services in a more efficient way than State governments. The most fundamental question which Australia will face in the long term surely must be whether the present three levels of government are the most appropriate way in which the needs and aspirations of the Australian people can be satisfied. Change to the structure of government will be gradual and difficult. However, in my opinion it is inevitable.

Australians are overgoverned. The conflict between national interest and State jealousies is too damaging to let continue into the next 200 years. The starting point for change is at the level of local government. Local authority areas should be rationalised and regionalised. Its powers should be defined, and within those powers it should be able to make decisions without fear of divine intervention by State governments. The overriding touchstone should be the national interest, determined by this Parliament. It is against this background, I believe, that the case for constitutional recognition of local government must be viewed. Such recognition, if in an appropriate form, will safeguard its existence as the most efficient form of government, most amenable to democratic expressions of public will.

I welcome the comments of the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) to the annual conference of the Local Government Association of Queensland. The Minister reaffirmed her strong support and that of her Department for constitutional recognition, although she did expressly state that this of itself would not bring major alterations to the present Federal system. This is the correct position, and I am hopeful that the Constitutional Commission will recommend change and that this recommendation will be taken on board by the Government and put to the public in Australia's bicentennial year.

There is one final matter on with I feel obliged to touch, given that it was Andrew Fisher's Government which put public ownership on the political agenda. As I said earlier, it was the Fisher Government which established the Commonwealth Bank. The future of the bank and other public enterprises is now being debated. It is a debate which, I believe, is worth while, as no institution, be it political or economic, should be immune from scrutiny. Generally, I think government enterprises have played and continue to play a significant role in Australia's economic development. The Commonwealth Bank competes with private banks and provides an equivalent service, which some suggest is not enough to justify its ownership in public hands.

In my opinion, government enterprises should not be restricted to fields which private enterprise does not wish to touch. If the Commonwealth Bank is profitable, its profits bolster Federal finances. There is nothing wrong with this. If the Commonwealth Bank is not profitable, then the examination should be on ways to make the bank profitable. I reject totally the argument that public enterprises are inherently less efficient than private businesses. In short, while I am willing to listen to arguments on the future of government enterprises, the onus is on those who propose sale or restructure to carry the debate and prove how the public will benefit by such changes.

Finally, may I say that it is a great honour to represent the people of Fisher. As the first Labor member for the division, I wish to assure all residents of my commitment to act on their behalf regardless of how their vote was cast. As the youngest member of this Parliament, I hope to make my association with my electors a long one and to play a constructive role in the improvement of the quality of life of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my electorate of Parkes is a town almost 400 road kilometres north of Dubbo called Brewarrina. It lies on the banks of the Barwon River and services a district largely renowned for its wool growing qualities. It has a population of 1,500 people, about 50 per cent white and 50 per cent black. Brewarrina leapt into prominence last month when an Aborigine, Lloyd Boney, hanged himself in a police cell. After Lloyd Boney's funeral a riot broke out in Brewarrina. This led the local coroner, Mark Olsen, to state that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) had actively contributed to the cause of the riot. The allegations were denied by the ABC at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of my own inquiries into what occurred, I can only concur that the behaviour of at least some sections of the media was unethical, unprofessional, at times suspicious, often distorted, sometimes appalling and perhaps even criminal. As a result, I believe the terms of reference of the royal commission should be extended to encompass a full investigation of the role of the media in this incident. At the very least I feel some sort of code of behaviour should be laid down as to how the media ought to conduct themselves in such situations. What happened in Brewarrina has highlighted that no longer should there even be any hint of news being allowed to be manufactured or distorted which can lead to lives being put at risk. But first let me recount some of the events that led to this.

On 6 August Lloyd Boney was picked up in a police van and transferred into the police lock-up at around 4 p.m. He was picked up for breaching his bail conditions, namely, that he should not have been in Brewarrina; that he had to report at Goodooga daily; that he had to stay away from his de facto in Brewarrina; and that he was not allowed to drink. He had assaulted his de facto more than once in the past and had breached bail four times.

In fact, he had a long history of 21 court appearances with 36 charges against him extending back to 1973. These were for various incidents including driving under the influence, stealing, assaulting a woman, malicious wounding, resisting arrest and so on. One source recounted that Lloyd Boney told one of the locals on the day of his arrest, `If the police pick me up then I will kill myself'. Although he had a high blood alcohol level on 6 August, Lloyd Boney was not paralytic from alcohol when apprehended. He got into the police wagon by himself and walked to the police cell unassisted. In fact, the police officer had hold of his arm to ensure he did not bolt as he was known as a runner. The cell door was left unlocked to give him access to the water tap in the exercise yard in case he wanted a drink.

When the police officer returned to feed Lloyd Boney at 5.30 p.m. he was standing there with a sock around his neck, which was attached at the other end higher up the cell door. The policeman thought he was foxing at first as Lloyd Boney's feet were on the ground due to the sock that hanged him having stretched over time under the weight of the body. After poking Boney with his fingers the policeman quickly realised that Boney was dead and immediately acted to cut him down.

The officer was naturally very upset. His state of mind was not helped by the 20 to 30 telephone calls he had to take that first night, demanding information and making threats to him, including death threats. The calls kept coming from every weirdo group in the country. He hardly slept during the first three or four days after the hanging.

Two post mortem examinations were carried out on the body. This was the fourteenth death in custody this year and the forty-fourth since 1980. The location, number and circumstances must have triggered some sort of threshold with the media and the Government because it achieved nation-wide publicity and the Government has ordered a Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I might add that four whites have hanged themselves in custody since Lloyd Boney's death and numerous others have tried to kill themselves. However, these deaths are not considered newsworthy.

Not so Lloyd Boney's death. The ABC in particular poured a spate of journalists into the town. Despite all we hear of its budgetary restrictions it was apparently deemed necessary to have at least three of its crews duplicating the coverage; the ABC news, ABC radio and ABC Four Corners.

There was concern in the town at the excessive publicity that was being given to Lloyd Boney's hanging. With all the journalists visiting the town and the talk of possible trouble there, the citizens of Brewarrina were fearful that this constant stirring would inevitably be self-fulfilling. Lots of outside blacks, some of them stirrers and activists, were also coming in to be where the action was. One policeman told me, `Media were walking up and down the street asking Aborigines how they were getting on with the police. Some Aborigines were saying how they were continually hounded for comments'.

The policeman went on to tell me that unfortunately some Aborigines were often in trouble with the police and would say anything to the Press as their way of getting back at the police. To him there seemed little or no interest in obtaining the other side of the story. Others informed me that provocative questions like: `Are you fellows going to do something?; and `Do you think there will be any trouble?' were often asked of the Aborigines.

At one stage the Shire Clerk, Ern Wilson, received a telephone call from a man who called himself Jim West and who said he was from the ABC. He tried to goad the Shire Clerk into going down to the park to get the Aborigines there to put out the fires. He hinted that, if he did so, he would be given time on ABC television. This should be looked into also. I found numerous citizens who claimed that the media, nearly all of whom are thought to be from the ABC, were buying Aborigines alcohol. I am not talking about shouting a few beers in the bar, though I would have thought that the media would have steered clear of doing even that. I have here three declarations from citizens stating people believed to be ABC journalists were buying cartons of canned beer and cartons of bottled beer and two-litre flagons of Royal Reserve Port for the Aborigines. I will seek leave to table these declarations at the end of my speech.

In one of these declarations an ABC radio reporter is stated to have openly admitted buying `grog' for the Aborigines. I believe a written police report also confirms that Press groups were supplying the Aborigines with alcohol. People were, in effect, being encouraged by the media, and not always in an unconscious manner, to `perform', to `flex their muscles', and to `deliver'.

Most Australians will find this latter-day `mirror and trinket' approach by the media abhorrent. Every decent Aboriginal person must have found the media's behaviour degrading to their race. To buy cartons of beer and flagons of wine, as ABC crew people apparently did, must have seemed to some to be virtually plying the more gullible Aborigines with liquor to get them to perform so a good news story could be obtained. It seems that more than one ABC crew was involved at some stage or other.
Trevor Bormann, the leader of the ABC news team that was in Brewarrina, said on the Willesee show of 17 August in answer to a question as to whether they had bought the Aborigines any drinks:
`We didn't pay them money, we didn't buy a white man a drink, we didn't buy a black man a drink'.

Mr Bormann appeared indignant at being asked this question. I am not quite sure to whom he was referring when he used the word `we', as in `. . . we didn't buy a black man a drink', but, if he was defending the ABC, as I assume he was, it seems he was wrong. Some told me it was even his own crew that was involved. I do know that Trevor Bormann's crew flew to New Caledonia shortly afterwards and, lo and behold, filed back a news report that the leader of New Caledonia's anti-independence movement had blamed the Australian media for distorted reporting and for a violent confrontation that took place on the island. I do not have to tell honourable members that it was this same ABC crew that got exclusive footage of the Brewarrina riot on the Saturday night. Two Aborigines came to the motel where they were staying and alerted them to the riot. They raced off to film it and were granted an extraordinary immunity from any attack or missiles thrown throughout the duration of the riot.

One policeman who was desperately defending his life during the riot told me of his amazement at the verbal tick-tacking between one of the Aborigines and Trevor Bormann and his crew. Comments such as: `Did you get that?', `Yes'. `Did you see him do that?'; `Right'; and so on were common. I am told by police that an ABC tape exists which includes such or similar verbal exchanges to which I have just referred. I trust a proper inquiry will take this tape into account.

The actual day of the riot, Saturday, 15 August, was a sad one for Brewarrina. Lloyd Boney's funeral moved off around 12.30 p.m. Later the Aborigines started drinking in the park and lit fires there. At 7.40 p.m. a police vehicle was struck by a thrown bottle. At about 8 p.m. some Aborigines came out of the park, threw bottles and missiles at the hotel and shouted abuse, trying to get those inside to come out. At 9 p.m. the Brewarrina Bowling Club was attacked by the Aborigines with bottles and missiles. At 9.40 p.m. one of the two police, placed unobtrusively on the hotel verandah overlooking the park, reported that some Aborigines had again come out of the park and were throwing bottles at the windows of the Brewarrina Hotel. This was the start of the main riot.

One of the first four police on the scene of the riot recounted to me an horrific story of events. They went down to stop the attack on the Brewarrina Hotel, believing only about 15 to 20 people were involved. However, when they turned up something like another 50 turned on them. Another four police arrived later to confront a total of about 70 to 150 Aborigines attacking them and the hotel. The numbers fluctuated as they disappeared into the darkness of the park and later reappeared with new supplies of stones, bottles, firesticks and steel bars. Bottles and missiles were thrown through the hotel windows-aluminium beer kegs too. The doors were smashed beyond repair. Every window was deliberately broken. Police vehicles were wrecked, one severely. The publican told me the damage to the hotel alone would be around $5,000.

But it is what happened to those police during the riot or, worse still, what could have happened, that most upsets me. The police had only helmets and shields to defend themselves and a short wooden baton in their non-shield holding hand. The riot lasted a good 40 minutes. Terry McGregor from Coolabah, while protecting his head from one attacker, had the long bone of his lower leg smashed with a blow from a metal pipe swung by another Aboriginal. This caused a spiral compound fracture of the tibia. He fell to the ground and knew he had to crawl away quickly to save his live. However, while on the ground he was subjected to a barrage of bottles and missiles in a sickening, cowardly attack by the rioters. Apparently one Aboriginal was screaming, `Come on, we'll kill him'. It was only the courage of the other police who ran to cover him with their perspex shields that probably saved his life. Detective Constable Grant Connelly was struck a number of times in the face, causing injuries to his nose and mouth. His left leg above the knee was also badly injured. Both these policemen had to be flown to Dubbo Base Hospital where I took the opportunity to visit them.

In a display of what some might call a modern version of traditional Aboriginal hunting skills, a steel fencing post was hurled through the darkness like a spear at another policeman. It penetrated his leg to the bone and severed a nerve which leaves that lower portion of his leg numb. Yet another policeman had a large lump of wood strike the top of his shield with such force that the shield struck the sergeant in the mouth, lacerating his lower lip and loosening his upper incisor teeth. This same officer had his right wrist damaged by a bottle, his right knee hit by a metal pipe and his lower left leg opened up badly by the same metal pipe. One policeman was attacked by another Aboriginal with a beer bottle. The bottle was smashed over his head and, shortly after, the Aboriginal leapt on the policeman's back and tried to force the jagged glass into his throat. I find it extraordinary that neither members of the ABC nor the Sydney Morning Herald who were present when this happened bothered to give an account of this incident. In fact, the Sydney Morning Herald reporting on the riot was laced with inaccuracies. Its editorial on the riot was no better.

The list of injuries to the police present was extensive though, needless to say, they received scant mention in the media. The police feared for their lives-one I spoke to thought he would be killed. Some have had mixtures of nightmares, hallucinations and amnesia since their experience. There is no way our police should have to put up with such disgusting displays of behaviour by people who bring great shame to the majority of their race. I do not accept terms such as `frustration', `desperation' and `provocation' as sufficient excuses for these louts' behaviour. It was sheer good luck that someone was not killed. The police who defended the hotel in the course of their duty showed extraordinary courage and it would not be inappropriate for some suitable recognition to be made of their herculean efforts.

Some media reports said the `whites only' hotel's racist customers on the top balcony of the hotel were shouting provocative abuse to the Aborigines across the road. Some even ran stories of a shot being fired at the Aborigines. The facts are otherwise. All people, irrespective of their colour, may drink at the hotel provided they behave themselves. The hotel closed about 8 p.m. on the Saturday night, a good 1 1/2 hours before the riot started. This was done to try to avoid any trouble which appeared to be brewing in the park opposite. Since early that evening two policemen, including an Aboriginal liaison officer, had positioned themselves unobtrusively on the balcony so as to observe any trouble that might eventuate. They were joined later by the hotel owners and a couple of friends who were at the hotel at the time. They deliberately remained inconspicuous so as not to draw attention to the hotel. Those on the balcony had no conversation with those on the ground below and no shot was fired from the balcony.

Of course, a major question coming out of all these alcohol purchases in Brewarrina is: who was paying for it? One claim was made that the ABC may have used $1,000 to buy liquor for the Aborigines to work them up for the riot. I must admit that claim sounded a little dramatic to me-until some information came my way that I believe the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) or the royal commissioner should investigate. This concerned a member of Pamela Bornhurst's ABC Four Corners crew, a Deborah Harriet Richards. During her stay in Brewarrina she visited the Commonwealth Bank there. At this visit I am told she transferred $1,778.00 exactly from an ABC `locations account' with a number 083-249-092-022-221.085-3. She put that money into a savings account in her name-No. 605-440. From this account she was seen to withdraw $1,000 in ten $100 notes. All this would be on the records that the bank holds--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am concerned about the words that are being used in this debate by the honourable member. I refer to page 465 and subsequent pages of House of Representatives Practice, relating to proceedings before royal commissions and reference to specific persons. Considering the very wide nature of the remarks that have been made, now the honourable member is speaking about specific persons and evidence that could go before the royal commission, I believe that it is therefore bordering on--

—Order! The Minister has made his point. The matter the Minister raised has occasioned the attention of the Chair. It is always a challenging point that the House exercise its right to be informed on matters which properly come within its compass and also not intrude upon the affairs of jurisprudence when it might result in justice being denied. But on balance-and there is a precedent by Sir Billy Snedden to support this ruling-the Chair is firmly of the view that the royal commissioners will not in the least be influenced by anything the honourable member is saying.

—There are witnesses who saw her withdraw $1,000 in ten $100 notes. People told me they saw Aborigines in the main street of Brewarrina later with $100 bills in their hand-unique in Brewarrina in an off pension week. At first I thought this money was probably just a legitimate expense allowance or something similar. The only thing that did not ring true with me was why one would open an account in Brewarrina, and why one would take out $1,000 cash. I have never taken out that amount of money in my life, let alone in Brewarrina. It is not exactly the world's greatest shopping centre. My interest was quickened when I read a report that a Mr Bob Kearsley, who was reported to be a controller of news and current affairs at the ABC, denied that ABC personnel could have that sort of money to spend. When asked about the possibility of such an amount he reportedly dismissed the claims as nonsense, and said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our people would not have the kind of money on them in the first place.
Trevor Bormann said:
Oh look we're talking about ABC money. I mean we get enough money to get ourselves a motel room. I think we had $100 contingency. The claims are ludicrous.

If Mr Kearsley and Trevor Bormann are so adamant that they are right, I think that in the light of what took place in Brewarrina these financial transactions should be thoroughly investigated. If the claims are legitimate the girl deserves to have her name cleared. However, if taxpayers' money has been misused in some way that should be traced and exposed. The Minister must ask the ABC to reveal what sort of accounting procedures it used; what claims were made and paid; when this was done; have any amounts been repaid or adjusted; and, if so, when.

I would particularly like to know whose money it was that was being used to buy the cartons and flagons of liquor for the Aborigines by ABC media men and women. Did it come out of their wages or was it out of their allowances, and therefore taxpayers' money? In the statement I wish to table I see that $50 and $100 notes were tendered for the purchases. I should hasten to add that not all of the members of the media behaved badly. For example, Barry Lowe of the Australian and Angela O'Brien of the Sun Herald are two who took a very professional approach. However, the reputation of Brewarrina has been raped by the actions of a section of media people. They came to town to get a story and they got it. It was legitimate that they should come to report a newsworthy event, but it was illegitimate how they went about getting that story. The media had their thrill in the two or three days each of the crews spent in Brewarrina. However, the town is left with a legacy of their visit that will remain for many years. It is hard enough to attract staff to work in the shire office, the school, the hospital, the banks and so on. It will be even harder after the town's reputation has been wrongly further damaged. The town is also left to live with the racial tensions from which it was remarkably free before the media `discovered' them.

I return to my original proposition that some sort of code of behaviour needs to be spelt out for those who apparently cannot be expected to observe the normal tenets of reasonable behaviour and common sense in such delicate yet complicated situations. There also needs to be a full recognition of the almost aphrodisiac effect that the presence of the media in general, and television in particular, has on certain groups of susceptible people in society. In South Africa when the state of emergency provisions were applied the deaths fell from 50 a month to five a month. In one sense, the television cameras were killing 45 a month. There was an element of that phenomenon in Brewarrina. It was aggravated by the purchase of alcohol. A free Press clearly has responsibilities that go with the freedoms.
