TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Wentworth, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Speaker. Let me begin by congratulating you on your re-election to the position of Speaker. I am delighted to be here as the new member for Wentworth. I want to thank all of those who have worked tirelessly to get me here and who in other ways have supported me over many years now. Wentworth is a really great electorate which offers the full range of economic, social and political challenges. I am honoured to follow what has been a succession of outstanding members for Wentworth.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, my immediate predecessor, Peter Coleman, had a distinguished career as a journalist before entering parliament, was a distinguished Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales and, I suggest to the House, is one of the most underrated experts in foreign affairs and defence matters as well as having made a number of significant contributions to the development of conservative thought in Australia.

However, in view of my background, I am sure, Madam Speaker, you will understand that I might more naturally associate myself with one or two of my other predecessors for example, Sir William McMillan, the first member for Wentworth. I read his maiden speech when preparing for this debate and I was attracted to and shared many of the ideas he expressed about freer trade and commerce, fiscal discipline, the role of unions and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and so on. More particularly I associate myself a little more with Leslie Bury who, as the House would know, was a professional economist, a practical banker and a businessman who worked at the International Monetary Fund and, as it happens, rose to the rank of Treasurer.

Having mentioned a past Treasurer, I can easily move on to consider the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his 1987-88 Budget. I am delighted to be able to devote my first parliamentary speech to some comments on that Budget.

While one cannot deny the generally favourable initial reaction to the Budget in the media and in financial markets, I suggest that one should not be surprised if this initial success fades, and indeed quite quickly, in the coming months. The Budget is not as good as it first appears. It has a disturbing air of unreality, a disturbing air of chicanery and demonstrates a disturbing complacency which is really quite unjustified, given our current and prospective economic performance, and particularly given the magnitude of some of our fundamental structural problems.

The Budget certainly does not seem to express an appropriate degree of urgency about our current economic plight, nor to offer an adequate response to some of our economic difficulties-for example, the realities of our current world trading environment; our relatively poor growth and investment outlook; our excessive inflation; our very high level of unemployment; our persistent balance of payments difficulties; the level and burden of servicing our ever-growing international debt; the inefficiencies, inequities, complexities and burdens of our taxation system; the rigidities of our product markets; our excessive levels of protection; and the inflexibility of our wages and industrial relations system. Indeed, rather than genuinely addressing many of these problems the Budget seems to set out to create a series of illusions that would have us believe that everything will be all right.

The main illusions are that the Budget is balanced, and that the Government has conducted the most wide-ranging and detailed review of government spending ever carried out which it claims has resulted in the biggest, yet apparently quite painless, cut in government spending in 35 years; indeed, it claims to have had some scope to offer a couple of new spending initiatives in this Budget. The Government would also have us believe that it has delivered sizable real tax cuts without any new taxes, and in fact that it has continued the process of tax reform. It would also have us accept that it has removed itself as a net borrower from financial markets and has set about to retire $2 billion of external and domestic debts this year. The implication is that our debt problem is on the mend. And all of this is to happen with stronger growth, more jobs, sufficient wage restraint, lower inflation, lower interest rates, more investment and less debt and without any further pressure on our balance of payments! Indeed, the Government anticipates a sizable improvement in our balance of payments.

But, Madam Speaker, the illusions created in the Budget Speech are soon exploded, not only by listening to the senator in the other place but also by having a closer read of the accompanying statements-even though, I suggest to the House, they are perhaps among the most political and least objective accompanying statements I have seen in many years.

Let me deal with each of the main Budget illusions in turn. First, the so-called balanced Budget. The media have justifiably concentrated on the one-off nature of certain revenue items, especially the $1 billion from asset sales, the $2.6 billion to come from profit of the Reserve Bank of Australia and the $212m from the minting of new coins. The Government's flirtation with asset sales could certainly be short lived, particularly the way the issue of so-called privatisation is being handled, and if the Australian Council of Trade Unions continues to have its way. The Reserve Bank has also warned us that we cannot expect it to continue to operate so profitably in the future-the scope for substantial profits does not exist in its accounts any more-and it has also expressed a very strong intention in its annual report not to continue to intervene as actively as it has in the past. This suggests, as a number of spokesmen from our side have said, that the Budget is probably closer to $2 billion to $3 billion in deficit rather than in balance.

The second illusion relates to the suggestion of significant expenditure restraint. I would like to provide some facts at this point to back up some of the arguments of the senator from another place. If we initially take a longer term perspective of what this Government has done with government expenditure, we see that it virtually went on an expenditure binge in the first two to three years, shifting to restraint only in the last couple of years under considerable pressure from financial markets, evidenced by the collapse of the Australian dollar. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) noted in the House last week, if the real growth in government spending in this Budget had been the same as the average over the Fraser years, $22 billion less would have been spent.

In claiming significant expenditure restraint, the Government makes much of two things: it says that there has been a 2.4 per cent cut in real expenditure in 1987-88 and it suggests that government spending has again fallen relative to gross domestic product (GDP). Of course, the so-called 2.4 per cent cut is actually only 1.4 per cent when we exclude asset sales, which reasonably cannot be considered as expenditure restraint. I also suggest that it is instructive to exclude payments to the States and other levels of government, and to treat them separately. This exercise is most illuminating. The Government's restraint on its own expenditure has not been anywhere near as great as the Budget expenditure aggregates would suggest. Indeed, it increases slightly in real terms in 1987-88, compared to the suggestion of a decline, and in fact it is only now barely back to the level of 1982-83, before this Government came to power, when measured relative to GDP.

But even this suggestion of restraint is quite illusory. If we focus, for example, on the expenditure decisions in the May economic statement we see that the Commonwealth claimed that savings in its own expenditure, excluding payments to the States and asset sales, totalled about $1.6 billion. A careful examination of that statement suggests that about $700m of that amount was simply deferrals of expenditure, and $200m results from additional efficiency gains; that is, some $800m to $900m was deferrals and undefined efficiency savings; so only about $800m was real expenditure cuts, and that in a Budget totalling $78 billion. I suggest, Madam Speaker, that that is not much real expenditure restraint. Moreover, very few programs have been axed and virtually no functions have been cut out altogether. Since the May statement the position has become even worse. It indicates that the Government has virtually given up on expenditure restraint. New decisions since May add about $600m to government spending in 1987-88, expanding to add $1.3 billion in 1988-89.

There is disturbing evidence that the Government has skewed its expenditure towards transfer payments and big ticket items such as health, education, social security and welfare and public administration, all of which increase significantly in real terms in this Budget.

As I noted before, Commonwealth payments to the States and other governments have definitely been squeezed. Commonwealth expenditure on the States has fallen from about 10 per cent of GDP in 1982-83 to about 8 per cent now. But-and this is significant-it should be recognised that this restraint on the States has not been fully reflected in their own expenditure and therefore in aggregate government expenditure. The States have been able to sustain, or in some cases increase, their expenditure by exploiting various hollow logs-running down cash balances that they have built up through excessive previous borrowings in earlier years; asset sales of their own; levying their own, less conspicuous, taxes; extra borrowings; or whatever. I suggest to the Government that it is no good washing its hands of this State issue. The Federal Government has a clear responsibility for overall economic management. It is about time that it told us how it intends to make its desired restraint effective on the States. I suggest that this will prove to be one of the most important fiscal policy issues in the life of this Parliament.

The third illusion relates to the claim that this Budget reduces taxation and continues the so-called process of tax reform. Again, if we begin by taking a long term perspective, if the Government had maintained the average tax rate of the Fraser years it would have collected about $16 billion less in taxes in this Budget. The truth is that this Government has basically balanced its Budgets since it has been in government by tax increases. It has raised revenue by about $34 billion and expenditure by about $30 billion and the difference is about equal to the deficit that this Government inherited in 1982-83. It is also instructive to look at what has happened since the Government's 1984-85 so-called taxation reform package. The Government has raised about $18 billion in taxes but it has given back only about $6.5 billion in tax cuts. That is $2 for the Government and $1 for us, which is hardly tax reform. All we have seen-it is typical-is new taxes and increased fiscal drag or rip-off through inflation.

Clearly the suggestion of tax reductions and tax reform is illusory. There are significant real increases in provisional tax, company tax, fringe benefits tax, which will raise 33 per cent in real terms this year, and sales tax in this Budget. The overall real tax increase is about 1 1/2 per cent in this Budget.

However, there were a couple of good features of the Budget in the taxation area. I welcome the reintroduction of negative gearing although I am amazed at the Government's capacity to sell that mistake as a positive rather than a negative, having now backed down on an earlier decision. And I welcome the review of company taxation which is essential if we are to resume some of our earlier prominence as an international trading nation or to take our rightful place as a significant financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region.

The fourth illusion is the suggestion by the Government that it is retiring government debt. The Government claims that it will be able to retire about $2 billion in debt during this year-$1 billion in overseas debt and $1 billion in domestic debt. Will it really do this or is it just another illusion? The truth is that the Government intends to run down its cash balances by about $1 billion. These cash balances were built up last year by excessive borrowing. Effectively, the Government will replace overseas debt by that medium. It also intends to issue about $1 billion worth of new treasury notes. That means that it will be able to retire debt simply because it borrowed too much last year and because it is now substituting short term debt for long term debt this year. Yes, it is another illusion. Yet the suggestion in the Budget Speech is that our debt situation is getting better. If we look back into the accompanying statements we find this in Budget Paper No. 2:
Australia's net external debt is likely to continue to rise faster than nominal GDP during 1987/1988 and a further rise in the debt service ratio is expected.

The fifth illusion relates to the suggestion of wage restraint and its contribution to our improved competitiveness. The Government is far too complacent on wages. The Budget Speech states, for example:
We must make sure labor costs in Australia are competitive with those of our trading partners.

Yet in Budget Paper No. 2 the Government assumes for the purpose of its forecasting exercise that, basically, the two-tier system will run its full course. That means we will get a further first tier increase of 1 1/2 per cent, the second tier increase of 4 per cent will flow to most people, and the superannuation benefits will flow to a majority of wage earners during this year. As a result, the Government forecasts that average weekly earnings will increase by 6 1/2 per cent, which I guess represents labour cost increases of about 7 1/2 per cent or 8 per cent which is roughly double the average of our trading partners. That is hardly sufficient wage restraint and it is just another illusion.

The final illusion relates to the macro-policy settings themselves and the outlook for the Australian economy. Far too much weight is placed on the Budget alone and far too little is said about wages and monetary policy. Macro-policy is to be considered as an integrated whole. While a genuinely balanced Budget would be welcome it could still prove insufficient if the other settings of policy are not appropriately supportive or consistent. So the key question is whether the whole Budget strategy hangs together. Of course, the Government says it does. I suggest that that is yet another illusion.

In my view, the wages policy and monetary policy settings are far too expansionary to complement appropriately the Budget that has been brought down. It all hinges-and quite crucially as the Budget Speech concedes-on the balance of payments continuing to improve and sufficient capital inflow being sustained. In my view, this is the weakest link in the economic outlook described in the Budget. The Government is much more optimistic than I am on both growth and inflation. If my forecasts prove correct, it could be detrimental to our balance of payments.

Even accepting the Government's forecasts on these parameters, the foreshadowed improvement in the balance of payments is most difficult to accept. It is hard to see the assumed zero real growth in imports if activity and investment, which has a high import content, are as strong as the Government suggests. It is also hard to see that exports will rise by 5.5 per cent in real terms again this year in what are increasingly difficult export markets with rising protectionism in the United States of America and the possibility of increased trade frictions between Japan and the United States. It is hard to see how the J-curve will be sustained, given that it peaked out about four or five months ago. It is hard to see the Government's optimism on world commodity prices especially as the United States is becoming more concerned about domestic inflation. Finally, it is hard to see capital inflow being sustained if inflation proves to be stickier, if wages growth continues to accelerate, if the Government continues to force down interest rates in Australia while they are rising in the United States and other countries with which we trade, if our international credit rating is downgraded again or if-and this is important- the other illusions I have referred to become more widely recognised in financial markets.

The Government's Budget and its illusions are unsustainable. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is right; we should have cut expenditure more. I have an uneasy feeling of deja vu about this Budget, especially when I look back to 1984-85 when the Government was similarly awash with revenue, when it prematurely eased monetary policy against the background of a fundamentally weak balance of payments and a weak Australian dollar.

In thinking about this Budget I was reminded of the great escapist and illusionist, the Great Houdini. Apparently at his funeral two of his pallbearers were the famous Hollywood producers Dillingham and Ziegfeld. As they were leaving the church with the casket Dillingham apparently whispered, `Hey, Ziggy, I bet you 100 bucks he's not in here'. Just as the Great Houdini was ultimately unable to escape death, so too will this Government have to face the reality of a market correction which will surely come when the full extent of this great illusion, the 1987-88 Budget, is recognised in financial markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to begin by welcoming the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) to the House. I have a special responsibility to do so as the former candidate for the seat of Wentworth against his predecessor. He joins a long line of distinguished academics who have joined the Opposition ranks, including the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) and the former honourable member for Forde, both of whom I am pleased to count among my personal friends. I hope that as a former academic he can bridge the gap between academic life and the rigours of parliamentary debate. I wish him well in that rather difficult task.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I wish to speak also on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and I begin by reminding the House that the Governor- General, when speaking to the Parliament, stated:
The Government recognises the importance of prevention as well as cure-
in matters of health-
and will continue to promote activities directed towards better health. It will be developing with the States the first comprehensive set of national health goals and strategies.

I wish to turn my attention to that subject in this debate on the Appropriation Bill. The central thrust of my contribution tonight is that all members of parliament ought to be taking up issues of preventive health and, in particular, the major threat to public health in this country which is the use of tobacco and behind that, of course, tobacco advertising. I note that as long ago as 1977 the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare recommended that government action be taken at the Federal, State and local level to ban the advertising of tobacco. I do not need to remind the House that the person who chaired that Committee was no less than former medico, Senator Peter Baume, a Liberal Party senator. That Committee made important recommendations for government action, most of which have not been acted on by successive governments of either political persuasion. My view is that people who are concerned about matters of public health and the use of tobacco, particularly its promotion among the young, ought to work relentlessly in the course of this Parliament to convince the Government to act for the implementation of a prohibition on tobacco advertising.

My interest in this issue is not some newfound hobby horse. For the record, I want to make it clear that I have had a long-standing interest in the issue of tobacco advertising. I am proud to say that while I was an alderman on the Sydney City Council I was responsible for that Council adopting a prohibition on tobacco advertising on City Council property. I do not want to wear my heart on my sleeve, but let me serve notice to the tobacco industry that my resolve in this issue was intensified by the death of my father from a cancer which was caused by the use of tobacco. I make it clear that I do not intend to approach the issue in some zealot-like manner, but in a very calm, calculated and relentless manner, in order to awaken public consciousness about what tobacco advertising does to young Australians.

I am also proud to say that I have had the opportunity to work alongside other campaigners on drug abuse issues-not just in relation to tobacco, but also hard drugs. I have, as you know, Madam Speaker, a great regard for the work of the Reverend Ted Noffs and also for the Australian of the Year, Dick Smith, both of whom have been trail blazers, I believe, in raising public awareness about issues of life education in an attempt to combat the drug menace. I, like Dick Smith, reserve for special criticism the advertising of tobacco companies which seeks to encourage young Australians to take up the addiction of tobacco. I will have more to say about this later.

There is no doubt about the health effects of tobacco. The Drug Summit identified tobacco as the cause of 81 per cent of all drug deaths in Australia. Alcohol was responsible for 16 per cent of drug deaths, and deaths due to opiates amounted to one per cent of all drug deaths. As my colleague the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) has pointed out to the House, the so-called hard drug problem is, rightly, a major priority, but is massively overwhelmed by the magnitude of health problems constituted by tobacco and tobacco-related illnesses. The Drug Summit estimated that at least 16,600 Australians die each year due to tobacco smoking, principally from lung cancer, heart disease, strokes, chronic bronchitis and emphysema. Other reliable estimates have put the death toll in excess of 23,000 people. The Western Australian Department of Health has estimated that half a million more Australians will die between 1985 and the year 2000 unless there is intervention by government.

I ask my Labor colleagues to take particular notice of the statistics that show which groups in society have become the victims of tobacco, because there is clear evidence that working class people bear the overwhelming burden of smoking-induced illnesses and death. Builders labourers, storemen, council labourers and domestic service workers have the highest death rate from lung cancer, namely, 59.7 per 100,000, which is nearly three times the lowest rate, that for doctors, dentists and lawyers. Thus, Government members have a special responsibility in this area. However, I make it clear that deaths by tobacco usage affect all Australians, irrespective of their socio-economic background. It is perhaps for that reason that the Australian Labor Party national policy provides that we as a national government will, in co-operation with State, Territory and local governments, restrict the promotion, whether by direct or indirect means, of tobacco products and sponsorships.

There are a number of initiatives which health experts and the medical profession have suggested that governments at the State and Federal level can take to reduce death and disease levels due to smoking. These include increasing the price of tobacco by fiscal policy, education programs in schools and the media, bans on all forms of advertising and promotion, and restriction on smoking in public places, including work places. It is true-and I welcome the fact-that these measures have been undertaken to various degrees by governments of all political persuasions over the last 20 years. But I believe it is time for back bench members on both sides of the House to take a far stronger stand on tobacco advertising and promotion. Through this expression of parliamentary support I believe the Government can be encouraged to act.

I want to make my own position absolutely clear. I am intensely aware of the addiction which smokers have, and have never been an anti-smoking confrontationist. The number of times in my entire life that I have ever asked people not to smoke could be counted on the fingers of one hand, even though I do not like cigarette smoke. My personal attitude is that I normally put up with it, although I realise that my view is not shared by many non-smokers. My view is that if people want to smoke, it is their right to do so, irrespective of the consequences to their health, provided that smoking does not affect the legitimate rights of others. I want to make that absolutely clear because my campaign against the tobacco corporations is primarily directed towards discouraging new smokers-young kids-from taking up the addiction, and particularly to protect kids and adolescents from the effects of the tobacco corporations.

It seems to me to be an indictment of the values of society that a drug such as tobacco, which is a known killer, can be actively promoted by slick, deceitful, corporate advertising practices. We in the Parliament have a political and moral responsibility to take action to stop this promotion. There is a mountain of evidence, Mr Deputy Speaker-I feel confident that you would share my concern on this issue-that tobacco companies target young children. I will give a few examples. The National Times reported last year that the tobacco giant Philip Morris (Australia) Ltd had set up a network to sponsor Australian rock groups, in a bid to extend its influence in the lucrative youth market, by spending up to $100,000 in only three months in promoting the Peter Jackson rock circuit in Sydney. The Cancer Council-backed national public health lobby group, called Action on Smoking and Health, has pointed out that both Peter Jackson and Alpine have been heavily promoted among the young. Peter Jackson's popularity increased 27-fold in three years, while Alpine nearly doubled its percentage of children customers. Both products are made by Philip Morris and they are the only ones sold in packs of 15. The Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations has produced a report which concluded that women and teenage boys and girls are the prime targets of cigarette companies' advertising campaigns. The Federation believes that tobacco companies see young children as their future market base and that health warnings do little to dissuade them from smoking.

One does not have to be a psychologist or an advertising guru to understand to whom the tobacco and advertising companies are appealing, with youthful, glamorous, young male and female models, fast cars, exotic lifestyles, rock culture and small packets of cigarettes. Yes, you guessed it, Mr Deputy Speaker, members and mothers and fathers of Australia: it is your children who are being sought out as the future tobacco smokers of tomorrow. There have been attempts to prohibit tobacco advertising in the States, but they have been resisted by this fairly slick, well bank-rolled public relations campaign of the multinational tobacco companies. They have had political friends in very high places who have been prepared to defend their corporate interests and allow them to continue to promote their addictive drug.

I believe with great conviction that the tide is turning and that public opinion will swing behind governments that are prepared to act, and have the courage to act, on this important public health problem. In April this year the Australian health Ministers issued a statement to the effect that the current application of controls on tobacco advertising were unsatisfactory and that attempts would be made by them, in consultation with the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy, to seek an urgent meeting with the Media Council of Australia in an attempt to get some action. The Ministers said that, if this move were unsuccessful, they would have no option but to consider alternative regulatory controls.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I know that the honourable member for Perth feels very strongly about this issue and has had the courage of his convictions to take a stand on this issue. It is my view that there is only one socially responsible regulatory control and that is for the Australian national Government and the States to follow the leadership of the Conservative Government in Canada and ban all tobacco advertising. It is not good enough for those who control Australia's major newspapers and magazines to wait for government action. Those people on the conservative side of politics who have a view about morals, ethics and proper corporate behaviour, I am sure, would share my view that they too have a role to exercise some social responsibility in business and to refuse to take tobacco advertising, in the same way as the Toronto Globe and Mail in Canada which has adopted a policy of refusing cigarette advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that more and more parents are saying that they do not want to read advertisements about cigarettes because they are concerned that children should not smoke. Newspaper proprietors should take a lead on the issue. It is ludicrous that tobacco advertising is banned on radio and television and yet is able to be freely promoted in the print media. Australian of the Year, Dick Smith, is right; publishers should refuse to accept advertisements promoting tobacco and if they fail to act we, as members of parliament, have a responsibility to change the law to keep pace with community attitudes.

Having said that, I turn to two other important points. The first is the subject of smokeless tobacco. Honourable members may be aware that I have raised the issue of smokeless tobacco before in the House. If any member wants to know what this substance is like, at the conclusion of my speech he or she is welcome to inspect the packet that I have. It is a tobacco that is put in the mouth of the user. Like a tea bag, it allows the tobacco to be absorbed into the system. According to international medical opinion, it is clearly a cause of oral cancer. On 27 May this year the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) answered a question which I had put on the Notice Paper. I asked two questions. The first was:
Has the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) recommended that all forms of smokeless tobacco be listed as prohibited imports.
The Minister's answer was Yes. The second question was:
Will action be taken to implement the recommendations of the NHMRC in this matter; if so, when.
I was delighted that the Minister's answer was:

In recognition of the harm to health from use of these products, I have recommended to the Attorney-General that a ban on oral snuff and chewing tobacco manufactured in, or imported into, Australia should be introduced under the Trade Practices Act as from 30 September 1987.

I await the final announcement by the Government that it has acted on that commitment given by the Minister on 27 May this year. Secondly, I wish now to give a very dramatic example of the credibility of the tobacco industry in Australia. The major proponents of the tobacco industry are organised through the forum of the Tobacco Institute of Australia Ltd which recently made a submission to the Industries Assistance Commission. That Institute includes the major corporations of Philip Morris (Australia) Ltd, Rothmans of Pall Mall (Australia) Ltd, W. D. and H. O. Wills (Australia) Ltd and R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Australia Inc. The submission drew a number of fairly devastating conclusions and made some assertions that ought to remove for all time any doubt that any member of this Parliament would have about the bona fides and credibility of those companies. The submission stated:

The view that smoking is the cause of diseases such as lung cancer and heart disease is still an unproven hypothesis based on statistical evidence which at best can only indicate an association between smoking and ill health.

No medical practitioner in Australia could read that submission without feeling revulsion and contempt, as I do. The submission went on to make an assertion which shows the morally debauched level that the companies will reach in an attempt to justify their industry and in an attempt to stop us, as members of parliament, defending the interests of public health. It stated:

. . . it is sometimes argued that the government would save money in the absence of smoking since it would not have to pay certain sickness benefits to smokers and pensions to spouses of deceased smokers. Against this are old age pension savings which occur if smokers' life expectancy is lower than that of non-smokers.

Can honourable members believe that? Those companies actually raise the argument that implicitly they are doing the community a service by causing the death of all those Australians and, as a result, this Government will not have to pay old age pensions. That is absolutely disgusting. I do not apologise for the strength of my language. It is about time that we, as members of parliament, who share common concerns about public health, swept aside this pretence and took a common stand to cause governments to act to stop this outrageous promotion of tobacco advertising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time I have had an opportunity to speak in the new Parliament and I would be grateful, Mr Deputy Speaker, if you would pass on my congratulations to Madam Speaker on her re-election to that very responsible position. I am sure that she will serve this House well in this Parliament. I also congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is the first time that I have seen you in the chair. I am sure that you too will serve the House well in that position. I wish you well in it.

SPEECH.PARA: I assure the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) that he is not alone in his concern about the effects of drugs of addiction in Australia. I concur with most of his comments; I have some reservations about some of them. I assure the honourable member that he is not alone in his concern about the effects of drugs of addiction in Australia; many honourable members on this side of the House equally share that concern. We are playing our part to alert the Australian community to the effects of drugs of addiction and to alleviate for future generations that scourge in our society. My colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and I have been very active in promoting the `Life. Be In It' education program and we intend to continue to do that. I am sure that other members on this side of the House are also playing a positive role. I am conscious of the fact that the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) has been very active in alerting Australia to the effects of drugs of addiction. I assure the honourable member for Hughes and the House that this is a bipartisan issue and we share his concern. I assure him that, if there is any way in which we can attack this problem and deal with it in a bipartisan way, we on this side of the chamber will co-operate in every way possible. It is not a partisan political issue. It is an issue that is detrimental to the whole of Australian society. I am delighted to offer that response to the honourable member and I am sure that he will accept it in the sincerity in which I offer it.

It is not that particular issue that we are here tonight to debate. The subject that we are debating tonight is the Budget that was brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last week in this chamber. It is that issue that we have to address our minds to. I thought that the response to the Budget was very adequately summed up by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he responded to it last Thursday night. In one section of his speech the Leader of the Opposition said:
The past two days have seen an orgy of government self-congratulation and media hype, all of which has been based on the Government bringing down the deficit to only $27m.

I am sure that all of us in this chamber, and people throughout Australia, are conscious of the fact that the Treasurer brought down a Budget which showed, on the bottom line, a deficit of $27m. From that point onwards, from that figure onwards, when people cited that figure of $27m, it seemed that the media, commentators and financial institutions lost sight of all other factors in the Budget. That was the only thing that they could concentrate on-the $27m at the bottom line. The Leader of the Opposition was quite right in saying that the Government indulged itself in an orgy of self-congratulations. All of us saw that in the headlines of newspapers throughout this country.

Now that the dust has settled and people have started looking at what is really contained in that Budget and what it really means to the economy of this country, to the structure of our industries, to the structure of our society, I do not think there is so much hysteria about the one bottom line figure of $27m. We have to consider first how that particular figure was arrived at. It has been pointed out-and I am sure it is starting to hit home to people in the community-that that figure was arrived at by a very substantial sale of government assets and by Reserve Bank of Australia profits.

While I do not disagree with the Government retiring government debt in that way-I think that is quite responsible-we cannot delude ourselves that the economy is now way back on the track and that we can all sit back and content ourselves that Australia is now in a new era of prosperity simply because we have one Budget figure showing a bottom line deficit of $27m. That is totally wrong and any who believe that to be the case are simply deluding themselves. In fact, it was Senator Walsh who pointed out in very dramatic terms to the community just how misleading that sort of assumption might be. While we cannot assume that the Minister for Finance in the other chamber could ever be on the side of the Leader of the Opposition, it seems that on this particular issue they are at one. I quote the headlines from a couple of newspapers in recent days. The Australian newspaper on Monday, 21 September says, `Minister criticises Budget'. On the following day, Tuesday, 22 September, the headline in the Australian reads, `Walsh warns of IMF intervention'. Admittedly, these are dramatic headlines, but what Senator Walsh is really alerting the community to is the fact that we cannot delude ourselves that all of a sudden we have entered a new era of prosperity. If we listen to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and much of the media comment that followed last week's Budget, we could easily be deluded into that opinion. That is not the case. We in this chamber, the Ministers of the Government and the people in Australia need to look very carefully at where Australia is at the moment and not allow ourselves to enter into that self-delusion.

We have sold off government assets. The Reserve Bank has done very well in its trading profits. But those factors alone have not helped improve the level of the Australian economy. There is only one way, in my view, in which this country can be prosperous, and that is to work hard to produce and sell on the international market products that will return this country a profit. If we analyse the Budget we will find that there is no indication that that has happened and no indication that it may happen in the future. If we look at our balance of payments situation, it will be clear to us all in this chamber that this country has a very serious problem, and nothing in the Budget indicates that that problem is likely to improve in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —None at all.

—I agree with my colleague the honourable member for Dawson. There is no indication that this problem will improve in the future. But that is where the real wealth in Australia will come from. Until the Treasurer can show us that there is likely to be an improvement in Australia's external balance, anything else that might be contained in this Budget is nothing more than self-delusion. The Minister for Finance, in very dramatic terms, went much further than that. He claimed that we were on the Argentinean road. Perhaps that is dramatic language and Senator Walsh may have gone too far. But what he is doing in making that sort of comment is the same as the Treasurer was doing a little over 12 months ago when he claimed that we were heading towards a banana republic. Those two Ministers were trying to alert Australia to the fact that we have a very serious problem, that we cannot delude ourselves that there is a new era of prosperity upon us and that we have a long way to go before that will happen.

SPEECH.PARA: On this occasion the Treasurer seems to have lost sight of the economic goals that the Government, the Parliament and the country have given to him. It seems that the Treasurer is not acting responsibly in the way he is projecting the economy; rather, it is his political objective of wanting to be the next Prime Minister of this country that has overshadowed his economic management and his economic projections. It is commonly accepted around this place, and certainly in the Press gallery upstairs by those who follow closely political activity in this place, that the Prime Minister will retire before the next general election. We are all conscious of the fact that the position of President of the International Labour Organisation will become vacant during next year, and I wish the Prime Minister well in applying for that position. The question then arises: who will replace the present Prime Minister as Prime Minister of this country? I am quite sure that it is that question that occupies the mind of the Treasurer very actively.

This Budget, in the way in which it has been presented, is not in my view an accurate reflection of the real state of the Australian economy, nor does it alert the community to the problems they must address themselves to in the future; rather, it is a political document designed to help the present Treasurer become the Prime Minister of this country. The Treasurer is not acknowledging his responsibilities to this country by acting in such a blatantly political fashion.

The only way to get this country out of its present problems is to improve its productivity by showing that we can work hard and produce our products in competition with the rest of the world and sell them on the world market at a better rate and more competitively than do other countries with which we must compete. The Budget does nothing to help us down that way. In fact, it does not address in any way, shape or form the international problems that we face. I am sure that all of us are conscious of the fact that we have record indebtedness to overseas lenders. The Budget does nothing whatever to retire any of that debt. It does nothing to indicate that in the future that international debt will not rise even further.

In fact, our present balance of payments position indicates that this country, Australia Inc., is losing money at the rate of about $800m to $900m per month. That money has to be borrowed by Australia from somewhere overseas in order to pay our current bills for the products that we are bringing into this country. That is an horrific situation. We see figures regularly published in the financial magazines and newspapers that indicate that the overseas indebtedness of this country is in excess of $100 billion. The latest figures are about $108 billion to $110 billion. I know that for people who might work in rather ordinary jobs in factories and offices around Australia, such figures are way over their heads. They cannot understand them or that what this generation of Australians is doing is living at a standard, a lifestyle, which is above what we are prepared to work for and earn, to live in relative luxury in this generation. But we are committing our children and our grandchildren to pay for the debts that we are running up because we want to live at a high standard of living. Effectively, that is what the Government is covering up.

We are not prepared, and the Government is not prepared, to face the political reality that people in this country have two options: either we reduce our standard of living or we work a damned sight harder to pay for the standard of living that we want. At the moment we are doing neither. We are living at a high standard of living on borrowed money while committing our children and grandchildren to pay the debts off. This Government does nothing to address that problem.

The Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in their contributions to the debate on the Budget have pointed out that there is an urgent need for the Government to address the problem of government spending. Nothing in this Budget does anything to reduce the levels of government spending or adequately address the program to which government spending is directed. We are simply assuming that all levels of government spending and all programs of government spending will be maintained, and maintained at their present level. What that is doing is guaranteeing or enforcing that taxation will remain at its present level or increase.

In its May statement, the Government quite deceptively claimed that there were tax cuts on the way, and as I recall they were due to begin from 1 June. A lot of publicity was given by the Treasurer in the May statement to the fact that these tax cuts were on the way. However, if we have a look in this present Budget at the taxation collections expected during this present financial year, it is clear that there has been no real reduction in taxation. In aggregate terms, the levels of taxation collected by the Government will increase substantially. What the Government is doing is saying that it is not prepared to face the hard political decisions of cutting back on Government spending because it may lose political brownie points or votes, or its popularity in the opinion polls may drop. Because it is not prepared to face those political realities, it will force the taxpayer to pay more money, and that will make it look good in the opinion polls. That is not responsible economic management.

The Government is now taking the problem into a further dimension of irresponsibility, in my view, particularly with the introduction of the personal identification card system. What that now means is that the Government is saying, `We want to collect more tax, and in order to be able to collect more tax, we are going to impose this personal ID card system on everyone in Australia. We are going to plug every tiny little loophole'. Those of us in this place who are conscientious will recall that the last Auditor-General's report, released about 12 months ago, showed quite clearly that a substantial amount of money, in terms of billions of dollars, was not collected by the Australian Taxation Office simply because of bad administration within the Office itself.

It is my view that, if the Government is to be serious about the way in which it administers its affairs on behalf of the people of Australia, the first thing on which it should concentrate its attention is improving efficiency within the Administration. Surely it is much wiser to look at how it can respond to the Auditor-General's report and improve efficiency in the administration of the Taxation Office, so that legitimate taxation is collected through better administration, than to impose this personal identification system on all Australians, as the Government claims, for the reason of stopping tax rorts. What it does is make the assumption that all of us are guilty of tax rorts unless we are proven innocent by this personal identification card system. In my view, that is an unacceptable response. It does not improve efficiency-it merely covers up bad administration within that Department. I believe that this Budget as presented by the Treasurer is illusionary and deceptive, and does not properly address the problems that Australia is facing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your election as a Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives. I am sure that you will discharge your duties with fearless independence.

SPEECH.PARA: This, the fifth Budget of the Hawke Government, is an affirmation of unbounded confidence in the destiny of Australia. Moreover, it is a balanced Budget. The Australian newspaper, in its editorial of 16 September 1987, summed up the opinion of many when it correctly observed:

By balancing the Budget, the Government has thrown down the gauntlet to the private sector and the States. It has done all that could be reasonably expected of it. The pressing economic problems facing Australia-a chronic current account deficit on the balance of payments and declining business investment-can only be resolved by the private sector.

For the first time in more than 50 years a Government will be paying back some of the public sector's overseas debt. The cut in spending in real terms is the largest in 35 years. Moreover, the Government has insulated low-income earners and the deserving from the brunt of its spending cuts. It has been faithful to its traditional supporters and is entitled to expect restraint from the unions in second-tier wage negotiations.

This is a Budget for the benefit of all Australians and it is a Budget that has been endorsed by the overwhelming majority of Australians. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and join with millions of my fellow Australians in recording my appreciation of his outstanding achievement in bringing about a Budget of fairness and fiscal responsibility. The centrepiece of the fifth Keating Budget is the family allowance package. More than a million children will benefit from the package, which will provide a means tested family allowance supplement of $22 per week per child, and a higher rate of $28 per week for children aged between 13 and 15. This allowance will be paid on top of the existing family allowance. The family allowance package is the top priority of the Hawke Government during its third term. This package represents the first step by the Hawke Government to fulfil its historic pledge during the election campaign that by 1990 no Australian child need be living in poverty. However, as I have said, it is a Budget for all Australians. I shall now deal with the other important areas of the Budget.

First, I refer to defence, as nearly 11 per cent of the Australian Army is based in Townsville, which is also the site of a major Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base. This Budget permits essential capital re-equipment to proceed as quickly as possible and places additional emphasis on defence force accommodation and conditions of service. The Department of Defence will spend nearly $7.5 billion in 1987-88, providing an average real growth in defence spending of 1.7 per cent a year over the first five years of the Hawke Government. Seventy-five million dollars will be spent on defence housing in 1987-88 and a further $60m will be committed this year as part of a program to upgrade single living accommodation. The most significant portion of this program is the upgrading of 39 accommodation buildings at Lavarack Barracks in Townsville. The estimated cost is $16.7m. The Townsville program will convert 2,808 existing bed spaces currently in a four-man room configuration into 312 separate modules each comprising four individual bedrooms of about 12 square metres, a common room shared by the four occupants and a shared en suite.

The proposed design closely resembles the intent of services scales and standards of accommodation and will also provide carpets and curtains in the bedrooms and common room, new built-in furniture, including a bed, desk, shelving and wardrobes, a change room per building for living-out personnel and a complete upgrading of building fabric services. The program is proposed to commence in 1988 and be completed by late 1992. It will provide permanent living-in accommodation which is comparable with community standards of privacy, amenity and security. Because of the size of the project, it is necessary to refer the work to the Standing Committee on Public Works. This is planned to occur in late 1987 or early 1988. To the 3,500 Army personnel in Townsville this is an important government initiative.

The Budget also includes provision for the payment of $94m against the purchase of 39 Blackhawk helicopters to supplement the existing fleet of Iroquois helicopters. Deliveries are to commence in November 1987. These helicopters will be based at Townsvillle and will give the 3rd Brigade the capacity to airlift a company of soldiers equipped for combat. Work is already under way on the construction of facilities at RAAF Base Townsville for the introduction of the new helicopters. The Budget also includes provision of $14m this financial year towards the cost of these facilities and $1.4m for additional houses for defence personnel in Townsville.

North Queenslanders are especially proud of the Army Reserve in north Queensland. On 5 September 1987, in front of a brigade assembly on the parade ground of Jezzine Barracks, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced the re-raising of Townsville's 11th Brigade of the Australian Army. During the parade the Commander of the 11th Brigade, Colonel George Mansford, AM, was promoted to Brigadier. The Minister described Brigadier Mansford, AM, as a driving force behind the resurgence of the Army Reserve in north Queensland, bringing with him a wealth of experience to the Regular Army and the Army Reserve in the job of commanding the 11th Brigade. I congratulate Brigadier George Mansford, AM, on his promotion. He is one of Australia's outstanding field commanders.

The Brigade's history dates back to 1916 when it was raised as a World War I formation. The 11th Brigade now has three Army Reserve battalions, the 31st Battalion with headquarters in Townsville, the 51st Battalion, the Far North Queensland Regiment headquartered in Cairns and the 42nd Battalion with headquarters in Rockhampton. The Cairns based 51st Battalion, the Far North Queensland Regiment, is one of the Army's three regional force surveillance units with sub-units at Atherton, Innisfail, Weipa, Bamaga and on the Torres Strait Islands. The Townsville based 31st Battalion, the Royal Queensland Regiment, has sub-units at Bowen, Ayr and Ingham, while the 42nd Battalion, the Royal Queensland Regiment, has sub-units at Mackay, Sarina, Biloela and Gladstone. The Mount Isa based 35th Field Squadron is to come under the command of the 11th Brigade to provide engineer support and two new units will be raised for the Brigade, the 9th Field Ambulance and a brigade signals squadron. The 11th Brigade is now the most highly trained and combat-effective Army Reserve formation in Australia. Its current strength is approximately 1,800. Army Reserve recruiting in north Queensland over the past two years has maintained a steady increase. I am certain that within three years the strength of the 11th Brigade should stabilise at about 2,300 personnel.

Whilst the Government is investing much of its national treasure to improve the combat capability of the Australian Defence Force honourable members must be appalled, as I am, at recent calls not to exclude the Australia-United States alliance from trade talks with the United States of America. It must make millions of Australians sick with disgust. The ANZUS Treaty was signed during a period of great uncertainty in Australia. At the time, concern about communist expansion was uppermost in the minds of millions of Australians. More than 30 years on, the balance of power has altered. The military capabilities of many nations in the Asian and Pacific regions are much greater than they were when the ANZUS Treaty was signed. We Australians live in an unstable and unpredictable region.

Now, certain agri-political interests in Australia would have us place our security relationship with the United States on the bargaining table in our trade relations. Honourable members may well ask: what then will be our credibility as a true, faithful and trusted ally of the United States of America? It would be dangerous enough if there were to be a weakening of support within Australia for the whole alliance relationship but it would be a catastrophe for Australia if there were to be a weakening of support within the United States of America for its alliance relationship with Australia. If that were to happen, to whom and to what would Australia turn for its ultimate security? Apart from the United States of America, what nation is prepared to shed the blood of its citizens to guarantee the survival of Australia and its people? Ultimately, that is what the ANZUS Treaty, in essence, provides. What other nation would sign a security treaty with Australia to ensure the defeat of any military invasion against Australia? If the Australia-United States alliance were to fail, would Australia be able to play a significant role in defence preparedness on behalf of the Western alliance in this region, or would some Australians have us opt for a non-aligned, nuclear-free, self-reliant Fortress Australia?

The whole notion of the agri-political lobby, of placing our relationship with the United States on the bargaining table in our trade negotiations, is stupid and dangerous and must be soundly rejected by all Australians. Australia is imbued with the Western democratic tradition-and it must always be so. Inevitably there will be trade successes and disappointments, even between such allies as Australia and the United States. There have been and inevitably will continue to be trade successes and disappointments with the United Kingdom. If trade relations with the United Kingdom were to sour, what would happen then? Would that provoke a call by the agri-political groups for a weakening of support for Her Majesty, as Queen of Australia? I say it should not and must not. The Hawke Government has affirmed time and time again its resolute and unfailing commitment to strengthening the alliance between Australia and the United States of America. It has done so because this is essential to our national security and because the Hawke Government believes that as a free, democratic, Western nation, it is fundamentally right that it do so.

I now refer to Aborigines. The Budget provides for increased spending on Aboriginal programs. Total Commonwealth outlays on programs for Aborigines will be $671m during this financial year. The increase in spending on Aboriginal programs is striking evidence of the determination of the Hawke Government to eliminate by the year 2000 inequalities and lack of opportunities among Aborigines. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has guaranteed the Australian people that the Hawke Government is `determined to increase and improve the economic independence' of Aboriginal people and to ensure that `essential services are delivered to Aboriginal communities'. Furthermore, he committed the Hawke Government to overcoming the social and economic disadvantages which relegate Aborigines to being Australia's most underprivileged group.

There are approximately 10,000 Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders living in my electorate. Approximately 3,000 Aborigines live on Palm Island, which is located to the north-east of Townsville. Ninety-five per cent of the potential work force on Palm Island is unemployed. Many projects funded by the Federal Government have failed. Some examples are the oyster farming project, the fishing industry project, the aluminium boat building project and a horticultural project sponsored by the community employment program. I believe that incompetent management was the principal reason for their failure. The housing shortage is critical. Approximately 45 per cent of all Palm Island dwellings, including shacks, provide shelter to about 20 people in each dwelling at any given time. The extent of Queensland Government neglect of Aboriginal housing is a disgrace. A total of $60m has been allocated in this Budget for the housing of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. In addition, the Aboriginal Development Commission will provide more than $47m in grants for Aboriginal housing associations and nearly $16m for housing loans. Aboriginal Hostels Ltd has been allocated nearly $17m.

The people of Palm Island desperately need some of this money to provide basic shelter for themselves and their families. There is no industry at Palm Island and, apart from the tourism industry, I am not aware of any proposal to establish job creating industries at Palm Island. The Palm Island Aboriginal Council receives approximately one-quarter of its annual income-that is, more than $1m-from the sale of alcohol from the canteen owned by the Council. The balance of its income is provided by government grant. The Council cannot collect income from rates because it does not have a property base on which it can levy rates. Residents complain that they are unable to obtain title to their residential blocks. This is the fault of the Queensland Government.

Almost all personal income at Palm Island is generated by the payment of unemployment benefits and social security benefits. School truancy is a continuing problem. The high incidence of violent crime and public drunkenness often leads to heartbreak, hopelessness and frustration. The Queensland National Party Government has virtually abandoned its responsibilities to the Aboriginal community at Palm Island. The Federal Government must attempt to provide solutions to these problems. No one else has the will or the resources to do so.

Most roads throughout the Palm Island township are unsealed. The dust nuisance is a serious health hazard during the dry season. Passing motor vehicle traffic generates clouds of dust, covering pedestrians and babies in prams. The fine dust penetrates houses, the bakery, the butcher shop, the hospital, the day care centre, the nursing home and the general store. The ever-present dust causes eye infections, particularly in children, and is a carrier of disease. I have asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for money to seal with bitumen the major thoroughfares at Palm Island.

The Federal Government has increased by more than $7.8m the amount it will spend next year on Aboriginal student assistance schemes. The Government has announced that there will be changes to the Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme in 1988, although it will be maintained as a separate scheme. At-home students and non-approved boarders will receive a single fortnightly living allowance to replace the current separate living, personal and book and clothing allowances and payment of school tuition fees. A living allowance will be paid in 26 fortnightly instalments rather than the current 22 fortnightly instalments for living allowance and personal allowance and three or four term instalments for the book and clothing allowance. Parents will not have to pay fees directly to schools for at-home students and non-approved boarders.
The people of Palm Island are not happy with these changes. I have received a letter from Sylvia Reuben, a worker at the Palm Island State School. It reads as follows:
Dear Mr Lindsay
The new method of payment of moneys to Aboriginal students in respect to various benefits will seriously disadvantage the Palm Island State School for the following reasons.
It will disadvantage the school now and in the future and the children of Palm Island will not have the chance to have a normal standard of education.

At the moment parents do not know how to budget and I feel it is too much of the school administration to go down to the store and around the Community asking or begging parents to pay the fees for their children.
I feel you people do not realise how we live. We at times do not have at our disposal the facilities to-
1. Wire money to another town to pay boarding fees.
2. Purchase bank cheques.
3. Purchase postal money orders.
This is all due to our isolation.

I also feel you are not being realistic in asking parents who live on a Community like this with a high cost of living e.g. 350g coffee one week is $2.99, the following week $4.99 and the price in town would be around $2.80, to use this allowance money to pay education fees. People will want to have food in their house rather than paying education bills.

The Community feels the standard of educational aides, as supplies and equipment will decrease and we feel as a community we use these things we would like to see the money being put back into the school and not be wasted away. The Community at the moment has the use of the school facilities.

We as a community feel that in education our children the skills of Home Economics, Manual Arts, and Art that this is quite important for the students to have in later life. Aboriginal children are good at visual learning and doing, making things and if this money is cut they are going to miss out.

We feel we have no way of convincing the parents that they must pay part of the new allowance to the school as all they can see is a house, a cupboard without food, a fridge without meat and they will use this money for what is not intended for. Take for instance this week, 31.8.87 to 4.9.87, the School had to pay for children ($40 each) who were going in to Townsville to participate in a sporting activity because their parents didn't have the money to pay for it. Why should these children miss out because they are so isolated. We only have just started to have sporting activities (over the last 10 years) with the Mainland and we feel that seeing we have an Aboriginal Sporting Body in Canberra we the people of Palm Island would like to see an Olympic champion from Palm Island.
We wish that when you are putting through the Legislation you put a waive for:
1. Book Allowance $80.00,
2. Manual Arts, Home Economics, Art Allowance, $35 for each student
so that the parents will know and feel secure that their children's educational future is in no way being mismanaged by another white administration.

We wish to thank you for thinking of giving us a little bit of independence in our children's educational future but we feel you are going a bit too fast and we would like a lot more consultation in the future but it is great to see that the Government is trying to give us back a little bit of self-independence.
Yours faithfully, Sylvia Reuben.

That evocative letter speaks volumes for the aspirations of the Aboriginal inhabitants of Palm Island-the largest Aboriginal community in Australia. The Budget provides $68.76m for community development projects for Aboriginal people. I particular welcome the announcement that $1m will be provided to help unemployed Aboriginals to start their own business.

All in all, this Budget is one of restraint, it is one of responsibility and it is one of conscience. It will continue to lay the foundations for a long term Hawke Government, over many years, designed to serve the people of Australia, to provide laws for the benefit of all the people in Australia and to build a better and fairer Australia for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would also like to congratulate you on your recent appointment as a Deputy Speaker of this House. I certainly wish you all the best, as I do to all the other Deputy Speakers who occupy that chair.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the 1987-88 Budget. The speech of the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) gives an indication of the level of debate of economic matters that has prevailed in Australia for the last four years. I give as an instance of the level of the debate and the manner in which it has been stifled the comments that have been made recently by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in revealing-as the Treasurer did over 12 months ago in his famous banana republic statement-his statement over the weekend to the Labor lawyers of Western Australia. This is a fair indication of what is happening with the economic debate in this country. Instead of that being accepted as a refreshing view of what the Minister for Finance actually feels in relation to the economy of Australia, what we have seen over the last two days is the carpeting of a senior Minister of the Administration, a man who has had control over the finances for years. In a moment of truth the argument that he presented-a very real argument-has been stifled.

There is evidence of that in other ways. As the shadow spokesman on trade in the old Parliament, I had the opportunity to speak in this House on matters of trade on only two occasions in 15 months. Yet the collapse of our terms of trade has been given as the reason for the deep recession of the economy over the last 18 months. The other area where this debate has been stifled is in the newspapers, journals and bulletins of Australia. There is no doubt in my mind that when Gerard Henderson indicated the mentality of some of the economic journalists in following religiously the theme of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for economic revival and its faults he was referring to the fact that they have been led, in a sense, to the point where they are not prepared to question properly the economic indicators that are presented to us. I will give just a few examples of this in the last Budget. We have been told that it is a balanced Budget. In fact, it is $27m in deficit. I hope, as the Treasurer would hope, that the events of the next 12 months will push that to a surplus.

But it is not a balanced Budget. It is $27m in deficit. This year, for the first time that I can remember, an item of income has been used and displayed in the Treasury accounts as a deduction from the expenditure for the year. This allows the Treasurer to state in his Budget Speech of last week that there has been a 2.4 per cent real decrease in expenditure. What the Treasurer is actually talking about is net expenditure after applying $1 billion for the sale of assets, the sale of the Australian farm, in order to meet expenditure. In a normal sense one would think even the Treasury would have to admit that the sale of $1 billion worth of assets would be shown as revenue and not a deduction from expenditure. All of this information has been within the realm of the journalists of Australia to pick up to present the proper picture. But no, no comment has been made on it. Instead we have had presentations such as that of the honourable member for Herbert suggesting that this is the big day, that it is the Budget of all Budgets to solve the problems of the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the big day for the nation.

—I am glad the honourable member interrupted. Obviously he would have heard what Senator Walsh has just said about this Budget, that 200 programs could well have been stripped from the expenditure. He talked about the threat of the International Monetary Fund stepping in. Yet this propaganda has been fed so successfully to the Government members that their interjections show that they have not learnt the lessons.
—Brainwashed.

—They have been brainwashed, as the honourable member for Wide Bay said, by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They refuse to listen to the elements of reason that Senator Walsh exposed. That propaganda also has been successful with the Australian media. I want to compare the five Labor Budgets. For the last four or five years the Labor Government has administered Australia. Figures are available from Budget Paper No. 1, particularly Table I, which indicate Budget expenditure, revenue and balances over the last five years since the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) laid down the 1982-83 Budget. Since then the revenue collected by the Hawke Labor Government has increased by $33 billion. It is $33,774m more than in 1982-83. The figures show that revenue in 1982-83 was $44,345m. This has increased in this Budget to $78,119m-a massive increase of 76 per cent. The important point is that the consumer price index increase, inflation in that period, was a mere half of that figure. It increased by 36 per cent. This means that the revenue of the Treasurer, the revenue of the Prime Minister, the revenue of this Labor Government has increased by 40 per cent in real terms. And who has paid for this?
—We can afford it because we have taken taxes from you people.

—Taxes have been raised. Let me tell the honourable member who again interrupts where the money has come from. The Government has taken the money from the persons in the gallery, from the persons who are paying 1 1/4 per cent more on Medicare levy, from the persons who might be out of a job because the Government put in a fringe benefits tax against the businesses of Australia. They could quite well be the people the Government has asked to substantiate legitimate expenses, and they might not be able to. They are the people paying more taxes. I invite the honourable member to interject any time he likes if he wants me to make such points. There has been a 40 per cent increase in taxes for the taxpayers of Australia. It is the other side of the equation I want to deal with.
