The Australian Taxation Office is sending those clubs letters day after day, asking them to lodge tax returns and pay tax on exactly the same type of income. Do honourable members reckon that is not a rort? If they want to talk about rorts, it is significant that 12 months ago today I started a file-it is rather thick by now-which covers the travelling allowance and taxability of a parliamentarian receiving an allowance not for living away from home but for living at home. I have not received an appropriate answer to queries I have raised. I wrote to the Commissioner of Taxation eight months ago. I reminded him three months down the track and then five months down the track that I had not received an answer. I then had to go to the Ombudsman to ask him to ask the Taxation Commissioner why I was not getting a response. Eventually a response was forced out of the Commissioner, but it does not apply to the situation I mentioned. The letter, dated 15 July, applies to allowances and not to the particular situation that I was asking about, that is, what happens when a rort is perpetrated on this Parliament, on this Government, by a parliamentarian who gets a travelling allowance not for living away from home but for living at home, as indicated in the electoral rolls for the last election, thereby avoiding tax on the allowance paid.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, what happens when a person does not lodge his tax return on time and is given special treatment, treatment not given to any other taxpayer in Australia. I know of a particular case in the same year about which we are talking where a taxpayer had a demand made on him to lodge a tax return earlier than the Treasurer. He was forced to pay a penalty of $300 even though he was getting a refund, and to date I have still had no satisfaction from the Taxation Office as to why that particular taxpayer should be treated any differently from a taxpayer who comes from this Parliament. I have this file that goes back 12 months. I suggest that when talking about rorts in the system we ought to start in this Parliament and try to correct the situation ourselves. We have been sold a furphy; the Government has perpetrated a myth in the manner in which it has been able to sell its excessive expenditure and collections of excessive revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, let me first congratulate you on your appointment to the position of Deputy Speaker. I know that you will fulfil your job with the same high standards and distinction as the Deputy Speakers and Speakers before you in this Parliament. As this is my first opportunity to have a good look at the Opposition front bench and the new coalition, I would like to say a few words about the shadow Ministry. A shadow Minister, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), preceded me. He had 20 minutes at his disposal to try to confuse the voters of Australia. Imagine people such as my mates in Hotham, in the pub in Cheltenham or in their living rooms, who were listening to his speech--
—They were.

—Yes, they were trying to discern what he was saying. He was trying to say to them that they are worse off under the Hawke Government than they were four years ago when he was in government. They will not believe the honourable members because those in the pub, including the publican, know very well that they are much better off today and no matter what kind of figures or tables the honourable member pulls out, he cannot say to them that they are any worse off. They are much better off than they were four years ago when the present Opposition occupied the treasury bench. It left us as a bequest a deficit of $10 billion that we had to pay back first, and now we have finally brought down a balanced Budget, have provided enough jobs for the people, and still have had enough to give to those needy families who really need our support.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that the honourable member for Dawson could not produce his real leader, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. I feel deprived that we have not seen him in this Parliament. I think we are missing some fun. I was looking forward to the enlightenment I could get from the Premier of Queensland. It is most unfortunate that he never made it. However, some of his supporters are very interesting people. They belong to the flat earth Opposition. They still believe as people did in the times before Galileo Galilei who tried to teach them about the rotation of the universe and so on. But, of course, they are going back some centuries and they still believe in a flat earth. We are told that that flat earth Opposition has suddenly started to rotate and that it will be spinning so fast only a few of the fellows will be able to hang on. I wonder whether the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) will still be on his rotating merry-go-round come the next election. I suspect that he will be as forgotten as his incentivation. Instead of incentivation what his front bench has produced so far could be better described as ineptness or defecation.

Not wanting to be unkind to individuals on the Opposition front bench let me say that, collectively, they are a pretty hopeless bunch while the few talented fellows opposite in the Opposition still languish on the back bench. It is actually because the honourable members opposite are so hopeless that some of us on this side of the House have to be critical of our Government-a very good Government indeed-so as not to let the Executive completely off the hook. The Opposition has now had two parliaments in which to get used to its role. However, it has failed dismally. It will take a couple more terms for honourable members opposite to get used to being on the Opposition benches and we will certainly provide them with the opportunity to stay on there. In the meantime, I and some of my colleagues have to fill the vacuum.

I am not critical of the 1987-88 Budget. In general, I agree with many of its provisions, especially with assistance to the low income families and the needy in our community. I welcome the general thrust of the Budget which aims to force us to live within our means-some more than others-although I would have liked to have seen the provision of more incentive for investment and further development of our manufacturing industries, especially those in the export sector.

However, today I would like to debate the longer term economic outlook and our strategies. In the past I was critical of our policies of deregulation. While I admit that an overregulated economy is not a desirable climate for readjustment, at the same time, rapid and excessive deregulation prevents government intervention, where necessary, in the public interest. Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) shut me up before I had even opened my mouth when I criticised the free float of our dollar. Yet if we look at it today in practice the float is not as free and clean as the Treasurer wanted us to believe.

However, the debate on deregulation of our currency is in the past. Privatisation is the centre of attention now. When the word `privatisation' was first mooted by the Opposition our side, from the top to the bottom, flatly rejected it and quite rightly so as `privatisation' is only another word for economic cannibalism. Since then, of course, those who will benefit from privatisation-a mighty powerful group of the Establishment-have managed to persuade some members of the Cabinet of its usefulness. They engaged the top salesman of our country, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to sell the idea to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and he promptly put it on the agenda, even though he knows that he has as much chance of selling privatisation to rank and file members of the Labor Party as Cicciolina has of persuading the Pope to use condoms. However, the Prime Minister knows the workings of the ALP inside out. After all, he has just received his 40-year membership medallion so he knows that he has to persuade not the majority of the Party members but only 50 per cent, plus one of the gurus, at the National Conference. As any student of Australian politics would know, accompanied with usual arm-twisting and the occasional application of the blow torch to the soft underbelly, both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are powerful persuaders.

It is beyond doubt that the Australian Labor Party is opposed to privatisation. Let me just read part of the first paragraph of our platform on page 70, under the heading `Public Sector' which states:
Labor is committed to the maintenance of the Australian public sector. We totally reject conservative proposals of privatisation of public enterprises and services...
Not wanting to be accused of being selective in my quotes I will just quote another couple of paragraphs from our platform. On page 70, paragraph 30 states:

Labor is committed to the provision of essential community services, including communications, health, education and transport, through the public sector, and will strongly resist efforts to privatise such services.
Paragraph 31 states:
Strengthen the role of the public sector by ensuring adequate resources are made available to it to perform its important tasks and by restructuring priorities.

Undoubtedly the message is as clear and unambiguous as it can possibly be. The only argument that can be used against it is the Prime Minister's statement that the platform of the Party is not sacrosanct. I agree with him on that. I also agree with his statement of illustration-namely, that, after all, we had the white Australia policy in that platform and we changed it. Let me tell honourable members that we had in our platform of 1905 as the object of our immigration policy `the maintenance of racial purity'. Of course, we chucked it out. I was one of those Party members who fought for the non-discriminatory immigration policy that we have today and I am still fighting to eliminate discrimination from our immigration practices.

I agree that our platform is not sacrosanct and that it is, and rightly so, subject to changes. But let me remind everybody that proposals that are embodied in our platform came from constituent party units and so should the proposals for changes. I assure honourable members that when the sanctity of our platform was brought into question no proposal from any constituent unit of our Party for privatisation was received by the Federal secretariat-not even from blind Freddy. Only the Prime Minister insisted on behalf of Sir Peter or Sir Paul that the matter should be on the agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was riding roughshod over you.

—The proposal probably comes from cockies' corner but I am sure that it does not come from the postal or telecommunication workers or from any State branch of the ALP. But let us examine the merits of the proposal. Those who demand privatisation of public enterprises argue that such enterprises will be run more efficiently in private hands. However, they do not support their tenet with any evidence whatsoever. The fact is that there are efficient publicly owned enterprises, like the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, while at the same time there are inefficient private enterprises, like the notorious Nugan Hand Bank, which must be well known to my New South Wales colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as efficiency is concerned, that is a mixed bag. Public or private, there are efficient and profitable undertakings in both sectors while there are also companies, private and public, that operate at a loss. It is rather the quality of management, technology, capitalisation, the loyalty of the work force and competition that determine efficiency, and not the kind of ownership. After all, the privatisers do not have on their hit list the inefficient and unprofitable public enterprises. They do not want to take over the Victorian tramways or railways, the country fire authority or the like, but they are aiming to buy Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd and the Australian Telecommunications Commission at bargain basement prices. Each of these public enterprises is well and efficiently managed. One has only to read their annual reports of the past few years to see that they are profitable, and also to see that they are increasingly profitable. For instance, the operating profit of Qantas for 1984-85 was $62.3m and for 1985-86 was $44.5m. Telecom's operating profit for 1984-85 was $385.2m and for 1985-86 was $464.6m. The net profit of Australian Airlines for 1984-85 was $29.9m and in 1985-86 was $37.7m. The net profit of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation for 1984-85 was $237m, and for 1985-86 was $277.4m.

While I can understand that the greedy privatisers are all out for more and more profits, I am at a loss to understand why a Labor Prime Minister would be so keen to oblige them, especially a Labor Prime Minister whom I respect greatly because of his sincere and genuine feeling for the underdog. Are members of the Establishment so powerful that they can remove us from the Government if we do not oblige them? If that is so, I wonder whether it is worth being in office by their grace alone. Let the conservatives do their bidding. Do not force the Labor Party, whose members believe in human values, to sell out their beliefs for market values. We are not a party of shopkeepers and money lenders, but a party which was created to defend the ordinary people of Australia and their interests.

One has only to look at the British experience, which has proven that privatisation reduced the choices of those whose services are paid for by cross-subsidisation. Do not force us to sell our heritage. Let us keep in mind that the main beneficiaries of privatisation in Britain have been the merchant bankers, stockbrokers and underwriters. Needless to say, they are not exactly a typical cross-section of the community. So do not give me the bulldust that the proposal is in the national interest. The proposal for privatisation is nothing but a demand for the squandering of public assets, belonging to us all, for free plunder by the 5 per cent of the wealthy in our society.

I do not want to be dogmatic and support public enterprise per se. But it is essential to have it, first of all, to provide services where the private sector would not provide them because it cares only about profit and not social and other needs. For example, the cross-subsidisation by Telecom would cease immediately, to the detriment of rural subscribers, if it were privatised. I do not hear anything from cockies corner at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they have left us.

—They have left. Secondly, it is important to note that we need public enterprise because it often provides the only competition for private companies. Even if we agree that in difficult times we have to sell some assets to keep the business going, it is an unsound commercial proposition to sell the profitable part of the business to be able to hang on to the non-profitable bit. It is especially foolish when the people's assets are sold to finance government deficits. My colleague the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), one-time favourite economic adviser to the Treasurer, wrote a paper entitled `Privatisation: The Abandonment of Public Responsibility' concerning the sale of the Belconnen Mall for $50m, in which he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a particularly short sighted policy, for unless the receipts are used to reduce debt, selling capital assets to provide for current spending is a sure way to go bankrupt.
Harold Macmillan, a former conservative British Prime Minister, expressed his opposition to privatisation thus:
First of all the Georgian silver goes, and then all the nice furniture that used to be in the salon. Then the Canalettos go.

I add to Harold Macmillan's statement that, if we go down the path of selling the people's heritage, it will not be long before we burn our libraries, because the road from economic cannibalism advocated by the New Right, to the dark era of barbarism, is a short one. I conclude by quoting the most eminent Australian scientist, Sir Mark Oliphant, who said:
If we allow human values to be replaced by those of the market place-our civilisation, as we know it, will be destroyed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last 18 months this country has gone through a period of sublime joy, better described during that period as our having the world's greatest Treasurer and, by implication, the world's greatest economy. A mere six months later, in the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), we were facing an economic state of war caused, he said, by a decline in our terms of trade and therefore a drop in our overseas income. To suggest, of course, that that was the sole reason is simply to gild the lily in the worst sense of the term. But since then, and as a result of that, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us that Australia was well on the way to becoming, as he put, a banana republic. In the last few days-last weekend, in fact-no less a personage than the second Minister responsible for economic policy in the Government, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, told us that we were well on to the `Argentinean road'.
—Well down the track!

—Well down the track, as my colleague says. Is it any wonder, therefore, that the Opposition and a growing number of Australian people and commentators in the Australian media are now looking beneath the facade of this Budget and asking why both the Treasurer, and today the Prime Minister can talk about the golden age of economic change, which we are now told we are about to experience?

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister and the Treasurer together have now brought five Budgets to this nation. The history of the last five years is significant in that it has brought to Australia the biggest spending government in our history, the biggest taxing government ever, the lowest value of the Australian dollar, record interest rates, record foreign debt, the worst inflation rate compared with those of our trading partners-which is fundamental to the very issue raised by the Prime Minister a mere six months ago-the highest number of bankruptcies, and the longest queues on public housing waiting lists, while we see among the same people, the poor of our community, longer term unemployment than ever before. What is perhaps most significant in international terms, especially in relation to our credit worthiness, is that Australia's AAA international rating was stripped from us. I am reliably informed that before the last election Standard and Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investor Services Inc. were quite prepared to reduce it even further-in fact, to the level of New Zealand's rating-if it had not been for the enormous political pressure brought on those companies in New York because the Government did not wish to face the embarrassment of that action so close to a Federal election. This record stands in infamy. These are the tests against which the fifth Budget must surely be judged.

Earlier this evening the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who recently entered this House and who gave a most excellent maiden speech, described the 1987-88 Budget as `the great illusion'. I totally agree. Senator Walsh, that worthy man to whom I referred earlier, said last weekend in his memorable address to the Society of Labor Lawyers in Western Australia that the Budget may have been oversold. What an understatement that was! But what he went on to say was particularly relevant. He referred to complacency about our economic problems which will send us further down, as I noted earlier, the Argentinean road. Once again, we are facing Mr Keating's banana republic. Senator Walsh said also that the Federal Government lacked the necessary political courage to bite into indulgent social welfare programs and that Australians needed to hold down consumption and build up their savings. That is all so true and all so ignored in the very fabric of this new socialist model that has been put to this House in recent days.

Surely it is time to look beneath the veneer, to take some of the gloss off a Budget which has, without doubt, been accepted far too easily, with not sufficient probing by too many people who ought to know better. The indices which underpin our economic future-our likely employment prospects; the level of inflation; the health of the dollar both domestically and internationally; the question of our world commodity prices which are so related to what happens between Japan and the United States over the next year or so; our trade deficit, which is so relevant to our standard of living, our balance of payments, our level of inflation and our economic well-being-have been described in recent days, in terms of the Budget, as being far too optimistic. Yet Government members, one after the other, have stood up in this House tonight and on other occasions and have tried to tell the Australian people, with rising decibels I may add, that they must believe because the world's greatest Treasurer says that it is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?

—The world's greatest Treasurer, the king of the banana republics of the South Pacific, the first Australian to bring to Australia a true South Pacific bubble. The sad fact is that, as I said earlier, the likely international trends over the next year or so could well be absolutely against Australia's best interests. The Government, in this Budget, had the opportunity of insulating us against the worst of what the world can throw at this nation; and it failed. As Senator Walsh said, it did not have the courage to do so. The Treasurer came in here and disported himself the other night. He preened himself like a young cockerel and said that this Government-the first government to do so for 30-odd years-was reducing our external debt by $1 billion and our internal debt by an equal amount. What he did not bother to tell us was that what he was basically doing was simply transferring long term debt for short term debt. He was playing with the books because basically he has no intention of making that fundamental change which can come only by a reduction in the size of government expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government reduces its needs for overseas and domestic borrowing, we will see an impact on international money markets which will affect our currency and our rating and which will, therefore, reduce our demands for overseas currency and undoubtedly result in a stronger Australian economy. Instead of that, the Government took the easy options. I am not here tonight to argue the issues of politics and to speculate about how long the Prime Minister will be here, whether he is to go to Geneva in about May 1989 to take over from the Secretary-General of the International Labour Organisation or whatever. However, one could be suspicious enough to suggest that the very fact that the Treasurer, who claims that he has such courage, missed and refused to face the realities of the time, was because he did not want to upset anybody at this stage.

All members of this House should want to bring Australia to the position of being a more secure and prosperous nation. The greatest deficiency of this Budget was its failure to spell out clearly how government policies could provide for a better working environment for Australian people, greater productivity increases and, above all, a greater future for our children. As I have said, the Government has not attempted to reduce the size of government, despite all the rhetoric of the Prime Minister in the May statement and since then. The Government has even backed off on selling overseas airports. There were people out there willing to pay good money to buy those airports so that public money would not have to be spent on their maintenance, expansion and running in due course. Yet we are told by the Prime Minister that he wants a policy of privatisation. We have just been told by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), who spoke before me, that privatisation is not in Labor policy and will never be seen again.

Very little attempt has been made by the Government to reduce the overall tax burden on individuals and businesses. Twice in the last five Budgets, this Government has made a plaintive attempt to reduce both corporate and personal taxation. However, despite that, the level of tax in Australia is higher today than it has been since the days of the Great Depression. When the Government talks about introducing greater flexibility and responsibility to our labour markets, again there is a lack of ability by the Government to face up to the fact that a more flexible labour market is essential if we are to be able to compete on world markets and reduce our costs of production. Reducing the cost structure of industry through increased competition and government regulation-for that reason, we do not need new initiatives such as the Australia Card-is an example, again, of a government which talks so much, but when it comes down to the difficult, the hard, the right, decisions it is unwilling to make the necessary moves in that direction.

The Liberal and National parties believe fundamentally that there can be no doubt that one of the best ways in which we can improve economic expectations in this country is to change basically our taxation system and reduce the level of tax so we can increase incentive for both individuals and business. The Government claims that it has cleaned up the system. Yet, last week, there was a most extraordinary allegation on Friday night's PM program regarding a Business Review Weekly publication. A transcript of that program states:

. . . of the richest people in this country, big developers and so on-business men in the BRW top 200 had paid a combined income tax of less than a $100,000 last year. In the case of one of the country's biggest developers with assets of over 220 million dollars, he actually paid income tax on something less than $5,000, meaning that he didn't even pay the Medicare levy.

I state that allegation only for what it is worth. It came from a reputable source. Those are the very things about which the Australia people are concerned. In Labor's five Budgets we have seen more people in Australia becoming millionaires while another 700,000 Australians have been reduced to living below the poverty line. Yet we are told that we have a Labor government that is compassionate and serious about its concern for the welfare of the Australian people.

This year's Budget will collect $5.6 billion more in tax revenue than last year's Budget, and $3.1 billion of that will come from individuals. Yet we are told that the Government's tax cuts of last July were so generous and have done so much to help people. How is it, therefore, that the average person will pay $230 more tax this year than he paid last year? So much for a government that is serious about reducing personal income tax! In areas of government expenditure, the last Budget of the Fraser Government produced a deficit of $4,400m. Yet over the years we have seen that figure slowly but inexorably increase to a figure of $10,000m. We have an overseas debt in excess of $110 billion. We are passing to our children the worst legacy that any generation of Australians before us ever even dreamt of, and this Government is supposed to be concerned about people.

One of the centrepieces of the last election campaign-indeed, one of the bases of this Budget-was to be the Government's intention to reduce poverty. A key feature of the Hawke Government's election policy platforms-this was a pledge made by the Prime Minister-was that by 1990 no child will need to live in poverty. He has introduced in this Budget a new family allowance supplement, a family income supplement and uniform rental assistance. The Opposition applauds any step that can be taken which is correct and which will seriously overcome these fundamental problems. But for the Prime minister to say, as he did in the House this morning, that the Government's family assistance scheme was the greatest single step taken by an Australian government to address social problems, is absolute rubbish. This policy has been described by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), a member of the Government's own team, as a poverty package. Unfortunately for many people, that is precisely what it is. Saunders and Whiteford of the Social Welfare Research Centre at the University of New South Wales said in a report assessing the Government's child poverty package:

The Government's family package will have the immediate effect of raising the income of many pensioner and beneficiary families with children, but not to a sufficient extent to raise the majority of poor families above the poverty line.

Yet we have been told that by 1990 no Australian children will be living in a state of poverty. Despite whatever reservations we may have about this whole problem, there is not the slightest doubt that no member of this House-of the Government or of the Opposition-can draw any satisfaction whatsoever from a social system which is said to be leaving over a million Australian children living beneath the Henderson poverty line. It is difficult to escape the conclusion that child poverty over the 1980s has increased dramatically. The reason for this can be found in economic realities such as increased unemployment, to some extent the results of the Family Law Act and various other problems. One thing is clear: it has taken five Budgets for this Government to face up to this fundamental problem that it is responsible for the future of our children who are our greatest asset.

The number of children living in families in poverty before adjusting for housing costs is said to have increased from a quarter of a million in 1972-73 to almost 600,000 by 1981-82 and to over 800,000 by 1985-86. The instance of child poverty over this period has risen from about 8 per cent to just over 20 per cent. As I said, it has taken the Government five Budgets to work out a program to try to do something about it. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is sitting on the other side of the chamber, knows as well as I do that in his area of reponsibility-among Aboriginal Australians-the problem of poverty is as real as it is in any other section of the Australian electorate. I would not like it to be suggested that in this package-a poverty package as it was called by one of the Minister's colleagues-any attempt will be made to reduce the capacity of Aboriginal Australians to have access to these new arrangements compared with anybody else.

As a result of this analysis which has been done into the problems of poverty and the allegations of the Prime Minister that under this new arrangement so many people will be helped, I carried out a survey and came up with some interesting information. The figures show that under the Government's new scheme, single income families with two children and on $376 per week will actually have 10c less disposable income for every additional dollar they earn. Senator Walsh, whom I have spoken about before, estimated that there would be 20,000 families affected in a negative sense by the 110 per cent effective marginal tax rate which will be applied to them by the so-called poverty package. The Prime Minister conceded this in Question Time today but even that estimate falls short of how bad the situation really is, because it does not include large families, especially those with up to five children. My calculations, based on the only available data released by the Government, showed that many families will be hit by the 110 per cent tax rate. In fact, there are 43,000 Australian families who will be worse off as a result of this poverty package-worse off than they are in their present situation. This is because of the poverty traps which are built into the system. These are the families who will be worse off: families with two children, on $374 to $394 a week; families with three children, on $410 to $437; families with four children, on $450 to $480; and families with five children, on $590 to $620 a week. All are falling into poverty traps and all of them will be worse off than they are at present. This new arrangement creates a very major disincentive for families in these brackets to increase their income as they will be actually better off if they stay on lower earnings and remain dependent on social security. Yet I would have thought that the very purpose of the exercise was to give people the opportunity not to be dependent on social security, to give people the opportunity to be trained to get out into the work force and to be able to get the pride of achievement as individuals, to give men and women-especially those in single family arrangements-the opportunity to give their children at least a reasonable basis upon which they can plan their lives for the future. Regrettably this is not to be.

Julian Disney of the Australian Council of Social Service made the same observation. He said that hundreds of thousands of children will remain below the poverty line, especially if they are in sole parent families having to pay for private rental accommodation. In many instances they may be as much as 20 per cent-that is more than $40 per week-below the poverty line, yet we are told that as a result of this package by 1990 no children will be living below this poverty line.
It is perfectly clear that what we are seeing is only the start and let us hope that it will not be the finish of what is a very serious problem.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Sunday in Sydney there will be a great game of rugby league when the Woodger's Canberra Raiders take on the powerful Manly team. I wish the Canberra Raiders very well, and I do that because of a long-standing personal association with both coaches, Don Furner and Wayne Bennett and particularly because six members of the team come from that great State of Queensland. I wish Gary Belcher, Peter Jackson, Mal Meninga, Sam Backo, Gary Coyne, Steve Walters and the two reserves from Queensland, Kevin Walters and Les Morrissey, all the best.

SPEECH.PARA: I applaud particularly the efforts over six years of Don Furner. Don Furner learnt his football in the great city of Toowoomba under the tutorship of the late Duncan Thompson. He made the Australian team from Toowoomba and for those honourable members who are interested in sporting backgrounds Don Furner participated in the Queensland professional heavyweight boxing championships. In his corner were the representatives of the Souths Rugby League Club in Toowoomba including the fellow international Ken McCaffrey. In case people think workers are the only ones who go on strike, on that particular occasion the Managers and Trainers Association of Professional Boxing in Queensland were almost on strike because in the corner with Furner were rugby league footballers instead of registered boxing coaches and managers.

I have had a long association with Wayne Bennett. In association with the late Reverend Father Thomas McCormack, I arranged Wayne's first game of football with my old school, St Joseph's Convent School, in Allora against the Allora State School. I also had the very great privilege of being captain of a team which included Wayne Bennett's late father, Jim Bennett. I had a long association with Wayne's family. His mother is a great personal friend of mine. For the record, his grandmother, Mrs Brosnan, taught me ballroom dancing. He had an uncle called Eddie Brosnan who played in the front for the Kangaroos in their first match in England in 1948. I was particularly fond of Wayne Bennett's grandfather, Eddie Brosnan, who was a local herdsman. As a small boy I used to take cattle to the market. One day coming across a narrow bridge there was a carload of very prosperous looking fellows going to the races all dressed up in their best suits. They tried to scare the cattle off the bridge. The cattle were full of oats and were rather loose in certain parts of their anatomy; it spilt all over the car. When we got the cattle across the bridge the four fellows came back and wanted to fight us. There was grandfather Brosnan, who was 70 years of age, and Tom McVeigh who was 10 years of age. Wayne Bennett was educated by the Christian Brothers in Warwick and he made the Australian team from the All Whites Rugby League Club in Toowoomba. TALK.START.PARA: —During the election campaign and, more recently in the Budget, the Government has given a high profile to poverty. I was interested in listening to the last speaker before the adjournment, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), and the points he was making about poverty. The coalition is very concerned about this situation because of the ever increasing numbers of people who are drifting into and living in poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sobering thought that one of the great hallmarks of this Government is that it has increased the rate at which people move into poverty. Of course, that is not surprising because socialism is about levelling down. It is about a pea soup society-a society that is bland, and that encourages mediocrity. The bankruptcy of this approach is no more clearly seen than in the fact that this Government has created over 150,000 poor people per year. That is a record for any government.

Well may Government Ministers abuse Question Time with long winded answers that rarely address the question. While they bicker over whether Australia has turned the corner, is living in a golden age or going the Argentinean way, thousands of households are being forced to live on the breadline. The fact is that Australians have suffered the most sustained reduction in living standards for 50 years, and now the Government seeks to win the applause of people by saying that poverty for children will cease to exist by 1990. This Government has created 700,000 poor people in five years. The simple fact is that this promise will not and cannot be delivered. Does anyone know of any nation state without child poverty? Again, it is one of the token escapades that this Government likes to indulge in as a heartwarming exercise, but has no intention of ever fulfilling. It never fulfilled its trilogy or its promises about the Priority One program, and it has failed thousands of young people who will not have places in tertiary institutions at the beginning of next year.

Much of the poverty can be traced back to the change in attitudes to family life. Those changes received a hefty kick along by the late Justice Murphy, who promoted the disastrous Family Law Act, radical feminism and humanism. Since that time, the number of children living in poverty has increased dramatically as people avail themselves of easy legal options for divorce to run away from the fundamental adult responsibility of parenting. Family life has been trivialised by the Family Law Act, till today we have advocates in our industrial relations area saying that child care provisions should not be such so as to retard a career. The emphasis is that a career path is more important than the nurture of children, and that the next generation is second in line to career success.

This Government has raised community perception about rights but has forgotten to mention obligations and responsibilities. So, today, we have the Government trying to gain some brownie points in attempting to eradicate child poverty by 1990-poverty that has largely been created by the Labor Party's policies. This Government's record on poverty is absolutely disgraceful, but to make the claim that by 1990 no child will live in poverty is to show the chicanery, deceitfulness and tokensim of this Hawke Government.

The second issue is to reduce potential fire hazards on board aircraft. Quite clearly, that poses a problem. Both clearly have deleterious effects on people who choose not to smoke. Despite the pretence by airline operators, very clearly they are not meeting their current obligations. The reason I bring this matter before the House at the moment is not to oppress smokers in any way but simply to point out that with the current move to more economical and wide-bodied aircraft we will eventually move to the stage where the entire air system of aircraft will be recirculated. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak tonight about the closure by the South Australian Labor Government of the Belair to Bridgewater railway line that runs, of course, into my electorate. This decision by the South Australian Government is not a rational decision but a decision which is politically discriminatory and is made simply, firstly, to save money and, secondly, to save money in an area where the Liberals hold both the Federal and State seats. The South Australian Government is not prepared to make similar decisions where marginal seats are involved or where Labor members hold seats. I regard that as an extremely poor and arrogant way of conducting public administration. It is one more reason why the Bannon Government needs, sooner or later, to be evicted from office.

SPEECH.PARA: The Belair to Bridgewater railway service provides convenient and easy travel for students, for working and shopping commuters to the city, for elderly citizens as well, of course, for handicapped people with wheelchairs and for cyclists who want to take their bicycles to Adelaide. It is quite a way from Adelaide. The fact is that this passenger train provides a safe alternative to the use of a very overcrowded road-the Mount Barker Road-which has become increasingly dangerous as the volume of traffic using that road has risen.

Arguments by the South Australian Government, supported by the Federal Government, that it is going to provide between $100m and $150m to upgrade the Mount Barker Road are wishful thinking because nobody in the world believes that in the foreseeable future that Government will come forward with that money. The railway does provide a safe and convenient alternative to that road if only it was promoted properly.

It is also important to recognise that students, particularly school students, travel to city schools from the Adelaide Hills, as well as to the Blackwood High School, the Heathfield High School and the Marbury School in the town of Aldgate. Indeed, some 80 students travel from Blackwood, Belair and Upper Sturt to the Heathfield High School. These students will be monumentally disadvantaged by the selfish, discriminatory and politically-based decision by the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia. It is really an indictment of the State Transport Authority in South Australia that that Authority has done nothing to promote the very promising tourist potential of the Belair to Bridgewater railway; indeed, the State Transport Authority has persisted in using derelict, out-of-date rolling stock on that rail route and yet has used modern, up-to-date, air-conditioned rolling stock on rail routes that go into marginal electorates around the metropolitan area. This is a very sorry story, not only for the many hundreds of individuals who will be seriously disadvantaged by the State Labor Government's decision but also for the tourist potential of South Australia.

It is worth remembering, Madam Speaker-you will be interested to hear this-that Mark Twain, the well known American author, in his book Following the Equator, with which you will be well acquainted, referred to the beauty of the Adelaide Hills. You can think about Melbourne, Madam Speaker, where I believe you come from, but it has no beauty whatsoever compared with the great beauty of the Adelaide Hills. Yet access to the beautiful Adelaide Hills is being denied to many tourists because of this narrow-minded decision by the State Labor Government.

I regret that the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan), who is always in trouble, has refused to allow me to speak with officers from the Bureau of Transport Economics about the study the Bureau is doing into this rail route. I think that is again indicative of the attitude of the Australian Labor Party to this important railway. It does not matter if it runs into Liberal areas because half the population of Australia, who are Liberal voters, apparently do not matter. That is the morality of the State Labor Government in South Australia, which is carried on by the Minister for bungles, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support. I sincerely regret the way this important railway has been neglected, ignored and discriminated against by the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of members of this House some concerns which came upon me during the election campaign. These concern elderly people within my electorate. There are others for whom age has meant physical and often mental retardation, and hence they are in nursing homes.

I find it somewhat interesting to sit here on this side of the House and hear honourable members on the other side talk about dignity and fair mindedness when some of the people who espouse the political beliefs of those opposite pursue courses in the treatment and dealing with the elderly in our community in anything but a fair-minded and dignified way. We may ask who these people are who place themselves or are placed by their families in care. By and large they are females-as we know, females in our society tend to live longer-who have found they are either not wanted by their families, which is another sad indictment upon us all, or no longer able to look after themselves. Hence they need people of integrity to care for them and look after their every need.

We as a community need to be very much assured that the people into whose care we commend our elderly and our aged persons are persons in whom we can place that sort of trust. Are some of these people in whom we have placed the care of our elderly simply there to make money for themselves or the organisation for which they work, or do they genuinely care for and meet the needs of those people? Let us face it; all of us, we hope, will one day be aged. It is something from which there is no escape.

Aged people have made a very real contribution to our community. By and large they have made a very real contribution in the areas of voluntary work. They have given of their very best and they are deserving now of a life which gives them dignity and which allows them privacy and integrity. They should not be stood over by people who place themselves in roles of authority. They should not be threatened by people in positions of authority if they do not wish to think or act in certain ways. They should not be terrified when, at the stroke of a quarter to five, they must rush inside to place themselves at a table so that they can sit there and wait for 15 minutes for a meal to be served to them.

I raise this question simply as one who is concerned about the creation of a fair and compassionate society. That society embraces all of us, the young and the old, and it behoves us as members of this Government and as members of this place to work to ensure that the aged in our community, particularly those who are in institutions, are treated fairly, with dignity, and are able to have a choice over the very last days of their lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House to an interesting proposal for a centre for cold and remote regions technology, commonly referred to as Antech. A report on this subject was made to the then Minister for Science in early 1987. It is under review by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button).

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal essentially is for a centre to facilitate the availability of information to industry and to stimulate special opportunities arising from government procurement and the concentration of Antarctic logistic and communication facilities in Hobart and the growth of international activity in Antarctica. The emphasis on Hobart as an Antarctic centre coincides with the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the recent Federal election campaign that the Australian Government will raise with the International Antarctic Treaty Organisation the prospect of having the headquarters of the international treaty secretariat in Hobart. Hobart is uniquely placed in the world as a jumping-off spot for those who seek to venture to the Antarctic for scientific and other purposes.

An Antech centre would bring special benefits to Tasmania. It would be able to be a generator of employment, technology and ideas. It would be appropriate to enhance Australia's position as a centre of expertise and innovation in the supply of products, services and consultancy to Antarctica. It would have in its framework the objectives of stimulating not only public involvement but private involvement in Antarctic development. Essentially, Antech would be a practical, cost-effective organisation seeking to ensure its long-term survival. Initially, it would be dependent in its establishment on a government grant. In the first instance, the planners expect a cost in the first year of $400,000, but in subsequent years it would obtain its funding through licensing and other arrangements, through the use of design, the provision of data base information, publications, consultancy services and project management services.

It is envisaged that the Antarctic Division would be the focus for the establishment of Antech and that initial product development programs would relate to the division's needs. The proposal put forward by Lawrence Howroyd and Associates to the Government points out a number of opportunities which could be developed. Products and ideas with obvious commercial merit could be developed on a joint venture basis with manufacturers, with Antech providing expertise in aspects such as design, patents, copyright and tendering.

The proposal is detailed in identifying a number of such opportunities. For example, there would be a field personnel location device, which would be appropriate for locating people lost in the Antarctic. In that hostile environment, safety is often prejudiced by white-outs, blizzards and darkness. Similarly, the report proposes the construction of an Antarctic design standards building and fire safety measures. On a somewhat more practical but less tasteful matter the report refers to projects for the removal of human waste and waste treatment, which is, of course a problem in the Antarctic.

At 7.15 p.m. on a Wednesday in a week in which the House is scheduled under the standing orders to meet on the Monday and at 10.15 p.m. on each other sitting day, the Speaker shall propose the question-That the House do now adjourn-which question shall be open to debate; if the House is in committee at the time stated, the Chairman shall report progress and upon such report being made the Speaker shall forthwith propose the question-That the House do now adjourn-which question shall be open to debate. No amendment may be moved to this question:
Provided that-
(a) if a division is in progress at the time fixed for interruption, the division shall be completed and the result announced;
(b) if, on the question-That the House do now adjourn-being proposed, a Minister requires the question to be put forthwith without debate, the Speaker shall forthwith put the question;
(c) a motion for the adjournment of the House may be moved by a Minister at an earlier hour;
(d) any business under discussion and not disposed of at the time of the adjournment shall be set down on the Notice Paper for the next sitting; and
(e) if the question-That the House do now adjourn-is negatived, the House or committee shall resume the proceedings at the point at which they have been interrupted:

Provided further that, if at 8 p.m. on a Wednesday in a week in which the House is scheduled under the standing orders to meet on the Monday, or at 11 p.m. on each other sitting day, the question before the House is-That the House do now adjourn-the Speaker shall interrupt the debate, at which time-

(f) a Minister may require that the debate be extended until 8.10 p.m. or 11.10 p.m., as appropriate, to enable Ministers to speak in reply to matters raised in the preceding adjournment debate; at 8.10 p.m. or 11.10 p.m., as appropriate, or upon the earlier cessation of the debate, the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House until the time of its next meeting, or
(g) if no action is taken by a Minister under paragraph (f), the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House until the time of its next meeting.
Mr Young to move-
That, unless otherwise ordered, the following proposed standing order be adopted as a sessional order:
General purpose standing committees
28b. (1) General purpose standing committees shall be appointed at the commencement of each Parliament as follows:
(a) Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs;
(b) Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts;
(c) Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training;
(d) Standing Committee on Community Affairs;
(e) Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs;
(f) Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology;
(g) Standing Committee on Infrastructure, and
(h) Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

(2) A standing committee appointed pursuant to paragraph (1) shall be empowered to inquire into and report on any matters referred to it by either the House or a Minister including any pre-legislation proposal, Bill, motion, petition, vote or expenditure, other financial matter, report or paper.

(3) Each committee appointed under subparagraphs (1) (a) to (d) and (f) to (h), inclusive, shall consist of 12 members and the committee appointed under subparagraph (1) (e) shall consist of 10 members with membership of each committee reflecting the proportion of Government to Opposition Members in the House, namely, 6 Government and 4 Opposition for a committee of 10 members and 7 Government and 5 Opposition for a committee of 12 members. Each committee may be supplemented with up to 3 members for a particular inquiry. Government members are to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips and Opposition members are to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips.
(4) Every nomination of a member to a committee shall be forthwith notified in writing to the Speaker.
(5) Each committee shall elect a Government member as its chairman.

(6) Each committee shall elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.

(7) For a standing committee of 12 to 15 members, 6 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee including 4 Government members, and for a committee of 10 or 11 members, 5 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee including 3 Government members.
(8) Each committee shall have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any sub-committee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(9) Each committee shall appoint the chairman of each sub-committee who shall have a casting vote only and at any time when the chairman of a sub-committee is not present at a meeting of the sub-committee the members of the sub-committee present shall elect another member of that sub-committee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(10) The quorum of a sub-committee shall be a majority of the members of that sub-committee.

(11) Members of the committee who are not members of a sub-committee may participate in the public proceedings of that sub-committee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(12) Each committee or any sub-committee shall have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(13) Each committee or any sub-committee shall have power to move from place to place.
(14) Any sub-committee shall have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any sittings or adjournment of the House.
(15) Each committee or any sub-committee shall have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(16) Each committee shall have leave to report from time to time.
(17) Each committee or any sub-committee shall have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the relevant standing committees appointed during previous Parliaments.
(18) Each committee shall have power to confer with a similar committee of the Senate.
